campaign.story:
Introducing Modkit.io
We failed to reach our pre-goal of 1000 backers so this campaign is over but our work is still just beginning.  Please read our final update or visit Modkit.io to learn more.
Modkit.io is an Event Oriented Multithreaded Programming Language
Modkit.io is a new kind of programming language for the Internet of Everything for Everyone. It has a rich, yet surprisingly intuitive, multithreaded and event oriented syntax that will be familiar to millions of young students and educators who have been exposed to Scratch. And it works with Wiring, the microcontroller framework used in the Arduino IDE as well as development tools from TI, Particle, and Intel.  
Multithreading is traditionally thought of and introduced as an advanced programming concept, but it just means you can have multiple things going on at the same time. Event-oriented simply means things can alert other things when something interesting happens. Unlike most programming languages, both of these concepts are built-in to Modkit.io, not introduced as a complicated afterthought.
Supported Editors and Hardware
Modkit.io works with the most popular programming environments
Modkit.io works with the most popular microcontroller development environments including the Arduino IDE, Particle Build, TI Energia, and Wiring.  If your hardware is supported by one of these environments chances are you can use Modkit.io to program it and make use of all of your existing libraries! The boards in the image below have already been tested.
Modkit.io supports the most popular development boards
But we could never test the 100's of possible boards ourselves. Be one of our first 1000 $1 backers by June 1, and help us test Modkit.io for your favorite development hardware.
Help us test Modkit.io with even more boards by pledging just $1
Pre-campaign
Important: We will add additional rewards once we reach our goal of 1000 pre-campaign supporters. But if we fail to reach our pre-campaign goal by June 1, our campaign will be cancelled due to insignificant demand.
Unlike most Kickstarter campaigns that start giving out rewards months (sometimes years) after funding success and add additional "stretch-goals" once they reach their initial fundraising goal, like most everything else at Modkit, we thought we'd do things a bit differently. So instead of a stretch-goal we set a pre-goal that's actually not about money at all. Our goal is to get our new programming language Modkit.io out to 1000 backers before we even start our campaign!
Our official campaign starts on June 1, but to connect with our earliest adopters and potential partners, get important feedback, and gather stories about how you will use Modkit.io, we're offering 1000 backers a single download of our Modkit.io library for Wiring-based microcontrollers for the absolute minimum Kickstarter pledge of $1. If we don't reach our pre-goal by June 1, we plan to cancel our campaign and if we don't reach our final goal by June 30, none of our backers will be charged. So if we're not successful you will actually get your pre-reward for free!
What do we mean by Internet?
The Internet starts with local networks
When people think about the Internet they often think about being able to communicate with anyone and everyone, anywhere in the world. But the Internet is simply a network of networks and it all starts with local networks. The same Internet protocols that allow you to communicate with a website or service across the world, allow you to send a document to a printer or to stream content to a television across the room. These same protocols can even be used to communicate between different programs on a single computer or device. This makes the Internet both technologically and socially democratic.
What do we mean by Everything?
The Internet of Everything starts with Things
Just like the Internet starts locally, we believe that the Internet of Everything should begin with a single thing and scale up from there. When developing programming languages to talk to things across the world, it is interesting to think that the same languages people use to talk to each other are the very languages we use to formulate thoughts, make personal plans, and ultimately to talk to oneself. 
We've seen many tools and languages proposed for the Internet of Things that do not provide a way for things to talk to themselves and to other things across the room in the same way that they talk to other things or computers across the world. Modkit.io was designed to democratize and bring the true essence of the Internet to Everything.  Our preview Modkit.io library for Wiring is focused on the most local network of things, the individual components connected to a single circuit board, and helping them communicate with each other more fluently than ever before.
Who do we mean by Everyone?
Inspired by Scratch for beginners - Multithreaded and Event-driven for everyone
Most text-based programming languages and other serious tools for technology creation are designed for engineers or computer scientists. With over 40 combined years of research and development in STEM education programs, Fab Labs and graphical programming languages such as Scratch and Modkit for VEX, we took a completely different approach and designed Modkit.io for Everyone. Just as text editors like Microsoft Word and Open Office are used everywhere from elementary school to grad school and by everyone from amateur lyricists to professional lawyers, we do not believe well designed tools have to appeal to only one audience or use case. We have seen graduate students at MIT struggle learning programming languages and young students from low-income neighborhoods excel at the same. This unique and broad exposure has led us to see far more commonalities than differences across novice and experienced programmers and it inspired and enabled us to design a programming language truly accessible to Everyone.
Related Languages
Modkit.io comes from a large family tree
Modkit.io is influenced by a large family tree and has benefitted from extensive interaction between its designer Ed Baafi and the designers of some of the most popular languages used by hobbyists and in education. For Ed it started over a decade ago, when Amon crossed the same bridge you see in our video carrying a flash drive containing Scratch, a new graphical programming language from his advisor Mitch Resnick's Lifelong Kindergarten Group at the MIT Media Lab. Ed had experience teaching with Logo, one of Scratch's text-based predecessors, alongside one of its original designers Dr. Cynthia Solomon. Amon said that like Logo, Scratch was designed to make coding more accessible for kids and that just like hip-hop DJs would remix beats, vocals, and samples from existing material, Scratch was designed to let kids remix sounds, images and the programs that control them into whole new digital creations.
History
We founded Modkit to bring the same accessibility as Scratch to microcontroller programming, originally targeting Arduino compatible development boards powered by the C++ based Wiring framework which itself has its own rich history. But Wiring/Arduino was single threaded, forcing programmers to coordinate everything in a single event loop and Modkit's early tools suffered this same limitation. If Scratch allows kids to remix like an experienced DJ with a set of turntables and a multitrack recorder, trying to remix with a single thread of control is like trying to mix with a single turntable and only one track. It's not impossible but you need a live band and you need to tightly coordinate everything. If you want to make any changes you usually have to redo the whole song. It wasn't until Modkit partnered with VEX Robotics to create Modkit for VEX, that we finally had the opportunity to bring a new language into the world. Originally called Wiring++ to honor Wiring's creator Hernando Barragán, Modkit.io has been in heavy development ever since and sits behind Modkit for VEX's powerful graphical programming blocks.
Future
Unlike many Kickstarter campaigns that are complete when they produce a film, gadget, or electronic hardware and ship rewards to their backers, for Modkit.io our Kickstarter campaign is just the beginning. Once a physical item is shipped there is not much left to do but we understand that the nature of software is that it is never complete. This is why we are offering $1 rewards even before we start our campaign, but it is the same reason we need a critical mass of supporters and partners if we are to build a community around the Modkit.io language and meet that community's needs well into the future. We will update you about our plans for the future once we have reached our pre-goal, but if we fail to reach 1000 backers for $1 by June 1, we are afraid there may be no future for Modkit.io at all.


Rewards
1000 Early Adopters get a single download of our Modkit.io Wiring library for Particle, TI Energia, and Arduino
While Modkit.io is a programming language for Everything and Everyone, our pre-rewards are designed just for Early Adopters and Early Evangelists. Both rewards feature a preview release of the Modkit.io library that brings the Modkit.io language to popular Wiring-based editors such as the Arduino IDE, Particle Build and TI Energia. Early Adopters get a single download of the Modkit.io library for just $1 even before our Kickstarter campaign has actually begun. We believe that once you try our simple event driven multithreaded programming, and after we open up additional rewards, you'll want to increase your pledge so that you can continue to follow our development and make room for another early adopter to try it out.
100 Early Evangelists get a Modkit flash drive to help spread the Modkit.io language and show support
Early Evangelists receive a limited edition Modkit flash drive that will only ship if our campaign is successful. Use it to share the Modkit.io updates you'll receive for one year from our funding completion. We know that many of our potential supporters are educators or members of local Makerspaces and Fab Labs so this is a great way to pass Modkit.io along to others. While it is too early to decide how we will license Modkit.io, the preview will be released under a special license that allows you to share it with your colleagues, friends, classmates and students. Help us spread the word and we'll be sure to add some more reward tiers as these begin to fill up.
Modkit Team
The core Modkit team met while designing and running the first of over one thousand worldwide Fab Labs as well as a one-of-a-kind youth maker program called Learn2Teach, Teach2Learn. In alphabetical order we are:

Ed Baafi is the lead instigator and founder of Modkit and the designer of the Modkit.io language. In 2011 he dropped out of the MIT Media Lab to focus on Modkit and hasn't looked back. From time to time he gets a chance to write including a chapter on hardware and software standards in Building Open Source Hardware. 

Dr. Susan Klimczak is a self-proclaimed education geek who loves integrating art and technology in youth programs across Boston. She received a doctorate in education from Harvard University focusing on informal educational environments.  She is also a fellow in the FabLearn Fellows Program at Stanford University. 

Dr. Amon Millner is Assistant Professor of Computing and Innovation at Olin College of Engineering.  While studying for his PhD with the Lifelong Kindergarten Group at the MIT Media Lab, he helped design Scratch and related technologies. He is immortalized as a character in Scratch so you can program him to do your bidding.  

Collin Reisdorf is the designer who focuses on the user interfaces and experience for Modkit's graphical programming tools.  He taught himself programming while studying design at MassArt and has designed experiences for some of the world's most recognizable brands before Ed convinced him to join Modkit.


Credits
Modkit.io was designed and developed by Ed Baafi with support from VEX Robotics and inspired and adapted from Scratch from the Lifelong Kindergarten Group at the MIT Media Lab.

"Modkit.io - the Most Important Technology" stars Ismael and Sang, directed by Michael King and co-produced by Ed Baafi and Michael King. Music by Garrett Rose as an original interpretation of Watermelon Man by Herbie Hancock. Graphics, illustrations and type layout by Collin Reisdorf.

Special thanks to Melvin H. King, Amon Millner, Susan Klimzcak, Collin Reisdorf, David Cavallo, Arnan "Roger" Sipitakiat, Cynthia Solomon, Bakhtiar Mikhak, Mitch Resnick, Leah Buechley, John Maloney,  Hernando Barragán, Daniel Ozick, Paul Copioli and Bob Mimlitch.
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
The preview release of Modkit.io is already complete and we're offering a limited number of single $1 downloads before our campaign has even begun, so there is very little risk that our backers will not get a clear picture of what we have already developed or receive their copies of it. We also already have the flash drives in hand which is currently our only physical reward. The biggest risk is for our company and for the future development of Modkit.io which cannot continue without significant support.

Large companies like Apple, Microsoft, and Google have historically been the only players who have built successful businesses around programming languages and we are aware that there are not many established paths for us to follow. But we are not deterred. We believe that the current state of hobbyist programming languages and tools is so far behind and so badly fragmented that educators, students, makers, hardware manufacturers, media outlets and other interested parties will get behind our efforts to change this and create a viable business around the Modkit.io language and tools. But if you've read this far, we're sure you're already ready to support us. If so, thank you! We couldn't and wouldn't do this without you.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

campaign.story:
What are People Saying About Squishy Circuits?
"I used it at home with my kids and then at an elementary school science event where it was the favorite activity of the evening. Seriously, I couldn't get kids to leave so that others could experience Squishy Circuits." – LeAnne from California
"As a librarian, I'm always looking for new and innovative programs to do with kids. Squishy Circuits really knocked it out of the park." – Mollie from Texas
"I use Squishy Circuits during summer Maker Camp; in my Makerspace and share them with our STEM lab teacher. The students loved them!" – Judy from Florida
Play, Invent, and Learn with Squishy Circuits™!
Squishy Circuits uses conductive and insulating play dough to teach the basics of electrical circuits in a fun, hands-on way. Let your creations come to life as you light them up with LEDs, make noises with buzzers, and spin with the motor.
Who is Squishy Circuits for?
Everyone! Squishy Circuits has been used in classrooms, homes, libraries, and museums in all 50 states and over 20 countries. The stories and experiences we have heard are incredible, ranging from science fair exhibits to nursing home activities. Squishy Circuits has even been invited to the White House! 
Squishy Circuits is truly for all ages - we have led events with 3 year old students who easily grasp the basics with just a little individual attention and workshops with adults. 
How does it Work?
Squishy Circuits is very simple and is based on two play doughs - one that is conductive (electricity flows through it) and one that is insulative (does not allow electricity to flow through it). We are excited to have pre-made dough that you can purchase directly from our store, or you can make your own doughs with the provided recipes.
Power is supplied by a 4AA battery pack and travels through the conductive dough to provide power to LEDs (Light Emitting Diodes), buzzers, or motors. 
Squishy Circuits are easy to make! View our Quick Start Guide or check out this video which walks through the most basic Squishy Circuit.
What are Squishy Circuits Kits?
Lite Kit – The lite kit is the most basic kit and includes everything that you need to make your first Squishy Circuits light up quickly and easily. It is ideal for classrooms, parties, or events where every participant needs their own battery pack and wants to get started building right away.
Standard Kit – The standard kit includes most of the components to be used with Squishy Circuits for more design creativity. It does not include dough, but the dough is easily made with the included recipes and common kitchen ingredients.
Deluxe Kit – The deluxe kit is our most complete Squishy Circuits kit. It comes with more items than the standard kit and comes with pre-made doughs so you can start circuit building right away! This kit also includes a deluxe battery holder which has a knob that allows your lights to blink and buzzers to beep at different speeds.
How are these kits different than the older versions?
Currently we offer one Squishy Circuits Kit that is very similar to the new standard kit (view it on our current website and on Amazon), however we have made significant improvements and will be discontinuing the older style. 
The newest generation of kits have a brand new design that is easier to manufacture, are more durable, and are safer.
What do I get for Supporting this Kickstarter?
Why is your help needed?
Development and sourcing for the new Squishy Circuits Kits started in early 2015 and we have created strong relationships with our vendors. Now, we need the upfront capital to start production and meet our vendor's minimum order quantities. This is only possible with your support. 
Furthermore, we need your help to grow Squishy Circuits and bring hands-on STEM education to more people around the globe. Your support will allow us to expand the Squishy Circuits brand and develop additional projects.
We have an aggressive timeline and we are committed to delivering the new kits before the start of the new school year. 
Who is Behind Squishy Circuits Store?
My name is Matthew Schmidtbauer and my Squishy Circuits journey began in early 2011 when I was an electrical engineering student at the University of St. Thomas and had just started working with AnnMarie Thomas (the creator of Squishy Circuits) on the Squishy Circuits project. From the very beginning, I thought that Squishy Circuits was a fantastic idea – and I was very excited to be working on it. After attending several events, I realized that many people were looking for a single source for all of the components required for Squishy Circuits. As my mom stated, “I wouldn’t have bought this for you growing up. I wouldn’t know what to call these things, let alone where to buy them.” 
Although developing a business plan, sourcing parts, and building a website were not necessarily things I thought I would be working on during my free time that spring, I started learning more about the process and finalized the Squishy Circuits Store idea. By June I had gained permission from AnnMarie, Sam (Squishy Circuits’ previous student researcher and recipe developer), and St. Thomas to continue forward. On June 15, 2011, I filed the paperwork for Squishy Circuits Store LLC. 
Armed with a small loan from my parents, I ordered raw materials. Upon their arrival, it became quite clear that “some assembly was required” and my parents and I began producing Squishy Circuits Kits out of their basement and garage. By September I had the first versions of the Squishy Circuits Kits available online and had started selling them. Learning to juggle school, work, kit production, and everything that filled the spaces in-between proved to be challenge, but, looking back, I can only think of it as a positive, learning experience. 
Producing the very first Squishy Circuit Kit in late 2011
Fast-forwarding to present day, I am proud to have sold thousands of Squishy Circuits kits in over 20 countries around the world. Although no longer a student researcher for Squishy Circuits, I continue to be a proponent of the program and am a firm believer that learning can be accomplished through playing and self-discovery.
AnnMarie Thomas and Matthew Schmidtbauer accepting a 2015 Eureka Award for Squishy Circuits
About Squishy Circuits
Squishy Circuits was developed at the University of St. Thomas in St. Paul, Minnesota by AnnMarie Thomas. It began as a summer research project in her Playful Learning Lab with past student Sam Johnson, and quickly grew in popularity. It especially became popular when AnnMarie demonstrated it at TED in 2011. 
Today, the Playful Learning Lab continues to expand upon Squishy Circuits and works on developing new technologies. Squishy Circuits Store is proud to support the Playful Learning Lab by contributing a portion of all sales and developing new Squishy Circuits resources.
Matthew and Playful Learning Lab students at the 2015 National Maker Faire in Washington DC
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
Drawing upon our experience of selling thousands of Squishy Circuits Kits, and having spent over a year developing and sourcing components for the new kits, we are confident that they will be a high-quality product. We also believe that we have taken the appropriate actions to ensure a successful campaign and are even optimistic that our timeline will be accelerated and shipping may happen early.

We believe we have two major risks, mainly regarding quality and importing times. Regarding quality, we have done several prototype runs proving that our vendors can provide components built to our requirements. We will be testing many of the production parts and plan on ordering extra in case of defects. This will ensure the final products are high quality.

Our vendors are primarily located overseas which means our products must be imported. In the past, we have had delays (port strikes, customs inspections, etc.) that have increased the importing process by weeks. We have built in some time so that if these unforeseen circumstances occur, we can still deliver on schedule.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

campaign.story:
We've created a series of monthly-delivered kits that help you understand the fundamentals of electronics and how hardware and software come together so you can innovate and invent from the comfort of your own home. Thimble is a unique direct-to-your-door monthly delivery subscription that contains a project with electronic components to teach kids and adults how to build a fun and useful device. 
Our very first kit we’re launching through this Kickstarter is a WiFi-enabled robot that you control with your phone, tablet, or laptop. The robot arrives with everything you need to build the project and a learning app you log into to follow instructions. The learning app provides step-by-step tutorials to help you throughout the construction process and provides a community of other makers to share knowledge and best practices. 
By making the Wi-Fi robot, you will:
create an Android/iOS app that makes things move
understand how electricity, motors, and microcontrollers work
prototype your own ideas to improve the robot
have fun showing off your creation.
Get all the parts to build your project
Follow steps on our learning app to construct the kit
Your first kit: a WiFi-controlled robot
Learn to program the app that controls the robot
 Who is Thimble for? 
Thimble kits are for curious minds - kids and adults (ages 13 and up) - interested in building electronics on a monthly basis that want a guided path to learn through step-by-step instructions on our learning app.
For ages 13+ (soldering is involved)
Made for those curious about hardware and software: make things move!
Why Thimble?
Kids and adults want to be creative and develop the right technical skills to build something fun and useful. But they’re hesitant to jump in because:
they don't have the right project ideas
finding components is time consuming
they don't have the knowledge to assemble their project
That whole experience is a massive barrier and we’re going to fix it.  By offering monthly kits, we are bringing the makerspace to your home; it doesn’t matter who you are or how old you are, people want to understand how individual electronic parts work together to make something function. As you progress from project to project, you will learn the art of soldering, programming languages, micro-controllers, and theory. Our hope is that you will learn enough to build, operate, and manipulate your own projects in the near future. 
PLAY

 The Mechanics:
The Wi-Fi robot is built around the Arduino microcontroller platform which may or may not be included in the kit depending on the reward level you select. The robot shield plugs into the Arduino and contains the motor controller and wifi module. You program the firmware (low level software) on the Arduino to talk to the Wi-Fi module in order to connect to your wireless network and receive commands from the internet to control the motors and make the robot move. The Thimble app that you program (for Android or iOS) then talks to the Wi-Fi module via the internet (UDP packets, specifically) to discover the robot on the network and send it commands to move forward, backward, left and right. We also show you how to add buttons to the app to read from sensors that you can add to the robot. 
 Soldering is involved:
Assembling components involves some soldering and can be accomplished by following instructions on our learning app in case you’re unfamiliar. Additional tools will be required to assemble the project and future kits; they can be purchased on our website after the campaign and will be shipped with your reward (if you don't already own them). The tools you’ll need are a soldering iron, soldering stand, solder, wire, wire cutters, diagonal cutters, a glue gun, and a screwdriver.
What parts will I receive in my first kit?
16 parts and you put it all together
Learn how to assemble the robot and code by following tutorials on our learning app.  Once the robot has been constructed, kids and adults with no previous exposure to electronics or programming will easily figure out how to code the wifi-robot to move forwards, backwards, left, and right. If you’re already a pro in some or all of these areas, you can skip over to see only the parts you’re interested in. We will also guide you through writing an app for the robot which will work for iOS and Android devices.
Easy-to-follow pictures, videos, and engaging community
Once you’ve completed coding the robot, you can enjoy driving it around. If you’re someone who likes to push the envelope, we encourage you to get creative - modify it and add components to the robot to make it do all sorts of things. This is truly where Thimble kits come alive! For example, add a sensor to make the robot avoid obstacles, or chase your dog around the house, or blink an LED when the lights are turned off! To get you started, we will show an example of how to read sensor data back to the app you develop. 
Once you build the robot, program the app to make it move
 Our goal is pretty simple: To help you learn and build electronics in a more structured way. (without feeling overwhelmed!)
Future Kits:
Other projects you could receive in later months include quadcopters, alarm clocks, LED cubes, light control devices for your home, weather monitoring, and more. If monthly is too frequent, or you just want to try the first kit out, we can ship kits when you’d like them.
Sneak peek at our second kit: RGB LED cube with an integrated 9DOF IMU (accelerometer, gyroscope, magnetometer)
Control the color of every pixel (LED) of the cube, program it to react when you move or tap it
Over this past summer, we did a one-month pilot program with the Boys and Girls Club of Buffalo to promote their STEAM curriculum. We had 12 students participate. Before the program, none of the students had experience with electronics, soldering, or software engineering and after it, 9 of the students wanted to become engineers and further pursue careers in software and hardware. To support that effort, we are partnering with the Boys and Girls club for a "Give a Kid a Kit" pay it forward initiative: if you would like, you can give a kit to a kid at the Buffalo Boys and Girls Club. We can also send it to a school or afterschool program in your local area. After the campaign is over, we will send out a survey asking where you would like the rewards that you selected to go.
How it all began...
In December 2014, Dave and Oscar met on Hacker News and quickly realized they shared the same passion for the maker movement. They met up in person and shared their goal to find ways to better engage kids and adults in electronics. Thimble was finally ignited by idea of month-to-month kits accompanied by a learning app that would provide seamless progression into hardware without feeling intimidated or demoralized.
Together, they’ve been bootstrapping this idea for almost a year. It has taken them eight months to get everything ready for production; there was also the challenge of figuring out what parts should be included in the kit and what the educational content on the learning app should look like. All throughout, they’ve spent their time learning about manufacturing electronics, meeting with manufacturers and suppliers, building relationships with partners, and designing future kits. They’ve tested Thimble kits with Maker Spaces as well as organizations such as the Boys & Girls Club to make sure they’re making something kids and adults will have fun learning and building.
Also, the team was recently accepted into New York’s Next Top Makers Fellowship. It is a community-sourced incubator dedicated to connecting ideas like Thimble with local development in NYC.  
David Brenner and Oscar Pedroso
A big thank you to our friends and family whose support has helped make this campaign possible. A special shout-out to Ander Kazmerski and Alex Weiser, our videographers. Nick Barone and Jonathan Gorczyga from Helm, our graphic designers. Douglas Borzynski and the Buffalo Museum of Science. Vic Nole and the Innovation Center in Buffalo, NY. Matt Lehner and Megan McNally at The Foundry.  Flying Bison Brewing Company, Julie Almond at Starbucks and David Almond at the Corner Bakery. 
Whether you’re a student, a programmer, an engineer, a parent, or you’ve tinkered with things at some point in your life - we sincerely hope that we can inspire you to join us on our journey of opening the world of electronics to all generations. We’re starting our journey with Kickstarter because we believe the backer community will play an integral role in Thimble’s development. By launching this campaign, we’re not just generating pre-sales, but also forging relationships with a passionate community of makers. Your feedback will help us and your support will enable us to reach our goals. If you’re ready for an awesome experience of making, please support our campaign and spread the word! 
 Additional notes:
If you don’t want to receive a kit every month, that’s okay. You can purchase our Kickstarter kit first (wifi-robot) and always have the option to upgrade to our monthly service at a later time on our website.
Please note that shipping to any country outside North America and Canada may be delayed or cancelled depending on the feasibility of local product approval requirements or local import regulations. In a case of cancellation, we will refund your pledge. There may be additional duties, fees, or taxes raised by authorities in your country. You may need to take care of them yourself when receiving the shipment. We're working hard to make this as inexpensive and painless as possible.
If you’d like to know more about Thimble kits, please feel free to reach out anytime at oscar@thimble.io or david@thimble.io.
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
We are really excited about launching the first ever Thimble electronics kit. However, we know that the most important part of the process is that we fulfill our promise to you, our backers, and deliver your first kit on time. 

Though we have preliminary agreements with manufacturers, we’d like to mitigate risks for any potential road bumps along the way. Now that we have a working prototype, we will face new challenges related to production, packaging, and shipping worldwide. We are certainly ready and confident that we will deliver! Our mentors at New York’s Next Top Makers and our manufacturing partners will be a strong support system. We will rely on them to help us reach our goals. With their guidance, we are confident that we will deliver a high quality product to our backers. We will continue to work hard, and of course, keep you in the loop throughout the entire process.

We are happy to bring Thimble to life and help you learn and build electronics one kit at a time.

Thank you,

The Thimble Team
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

campaign.story:
We’re artists, advocates, curators, and exhibitors. We seek out the most audacious, weird, and beautiful digital art and get people in front of it.
What can we say, we have a rebellious streak. We want to throw a hack party in the Guggenheim. Install micro-controllers inside diamond skulls. We think the gallery world should just be slightly more fun. We think we can accomplish a part of that with huge hearts and a fist-full of wire.
MediaLounge is on a mission to blow minds. We're sticking cutting edge artists, art works and advocates into the same space and shaking it up. We're going to put tools in the hands of the public by hosting workshops from the very people who are developing award winning software and hardware that make digital art possible. We're going to scream from the rooftops that new media art is fine art, damn fine art.
We're going to fill the Westbeth Gallery with the wildest art it's ever seen. Those empty rooms won't know what hit them!
Calls went out. Emails were sent. Panels convened. In the end we selected a cracker-jack group of artists to present to you in November. This year's work is alternatively cheeky, innovative, and heartbreakingly beautiful. Presenting the 2015 MediaLounge roster! Click on each to be directed to their project page on medialoungenyc.com.
    From 2009-2010 MediaLounge presented the work of over 100 artists. We gave them time, space, and resources to realize their visions. Uncoiled, ran, tangled, struck, untangled, and coiled over 500,000 miles of cables. We hung kinects, cameras, contact switches, and iR. And lugged projectors on subways all across New York City. Some people might have called it bleeding edge. We just called it fun.
We’re ambitious. We want to bring you the best of the best. We want our artists to feel supported by more than just enthusiasm! We’ve got the space and a foundation of funds to put on a spectacular show. But we can’t do it alone.
It’s not easy to ship interactive artwork from Spain, or finance travel so all of you can meet the amazing creators of this work. As any organizer will tell you, events cost time and money. We’re throwing in the time, the space, the staff...we need your help with the money.
Here are a few things your donations will go towards:
Travel and housing: We’ve got artists, workshop leads, and panelists coming in from all over the world. Let’s get them here and make them feel at home! 
Shipping: Some works are heavy and very far away. Let’s get them to NYC! 
PR Materials: It’s going to be a kick-ass production and we want a diverse crowd to witness this happening. Let’s get the word out in a big way! 
Equipment: Many artists build and show their work on their own tools. While this is fine for prototyping In a long term exhibit like this it’s a lot to ask the artists to leave their valuables behind. Let’s provide them with the best tools.
Awesome support team: MediaLounge has an amazing team of volunteers that are making this machine work. Let’s get them a little green for their steam!
[Pledge $5 or more] Your Name in Lights: Ever wanted to know what your name would look like scrolling through a L3D cube? Now's the chance. If you want to show the world you give MediaLounge a big thumbs up, donate 5$ or more and we'll send your name through the cube and post an animated gif.
[Pledge $20 or more] OWLet 9 LED Animation Kit:  Make your own lighting sequence that turns on and off based upon the amount of light it receives! Combining creativity with electronics, this kit offers an intermediate electronic experience. From MediaLounge's awesome partners, Open Wire Lab.
[Pledge $40 or more] MediaLounge Cardboard: Inspired by The Memory of Aden Walker? Want your very own VR headset? Thanks to our partners Unofficial Cardboard that's totally possible. 
[Pledge $350 or more] 8x8x8 L3D Cube: Full color, works out of the box, but is also 100% open-source and programmable over your home's wifi. Download and create new apps for your Cube on CubeTube.org, the "YouTube for Cubes"! Regular pricing after November 2015 will be $399 for a kit, or $450 for a fully assembled Cube. From MediaLounge's illustrious partners Looking Glass Factory.
[Pledge $450 or more] VIP Soirée: Hang with the MediaLounge crew in style. campaign.story:
The Plan
To make a great pop record with a playful spirit, in the tradition of the Beatles, the Supremes, and Sam Cooke. That means good songs with a sense of humor, soulfully played, packed with hooks, and bursting with aural pleasure.
*Update 11/4: We've hit the first two stretch goals! I've just added the "Magic Pack" reward. This reward and all others above $222 will include this limited-edition David Hale LUNA MOTH print (the same design I have tattooed on my right arm):
The Songs
I've got a menagerie of original songs on hand, and here's what they're saying:
Live joyfully, live playfully, live honestly. Pleasure is good for you. Sex is fun. Shame is a waste of time. Women are powerful superheroes. Respect yourself. Fuck the haters. Loneliness hurts but we need it. Love hurts but it is also the point of living. Feel love (and pleasure, and everything) often, and with relish.
Here are two of the songs that will be featured on the album. These are demos, and have not yet blossomed into the fullness of their pop glory, but I think they give a hint of the possibilities!
Hot Night:
 Ravenous:
 If you'd like to hear the rest of these demos, plus the other songs we're taking into the studio, become a backer!
The Money
I'm asking for $22,000. What I actually need to complete the record is $29,500. Whatever I don't make here, I will borrow (or steal, or beg for). To realize my ultimate vision for the record, which includes extra studio time and more musicians, I need about $36,000. To hire a publicity team who will see that the album gets heard far and wide, I need about $50,000.
My ultimate stretch goal is $69,000. If I were to reach that (incredible, beautiful, astronomical) number, I could make music videos for three of the singles from the album, hire the best (and fanciest) publicist in the business, and order additional CDs and vinyl. And, of course, sexy numbers are good luck.
For more info on the budget, scroll down.
Who do you think you are?
I'm a singer/songwriter living in New Orleans (by way of Philadelphia PA, Eugene OR, and Luray VA). I've been making records for ten years, writing and performing for fifteen, and singing my whole life. I've been interviewed on NPR and toured as an opener for Paul Simon, The Weepies, The Wood Brothers and many more. My last Kickstarter made over $60K, and resulted in a damn fine record, too.  
New to my music? Catch up at www.carsieblanton.com!   
Think crowdfunding is the bomb? I agree. Visit my Patreon page!
Why pop?
Well... I love pop. I love the attitude of pop: playful, joyful, unabashed, hedonistic. I love the sound of pop: melodic, lush, groove-laden, hook-driven. And I love so many of the artists who have been called "pop" over the last century: Nat King Cole, Paul Simon, Carole King, Michael Jackson, Dolly Parton, right up to Beyonce and Bruno Mars.
I also love that pop is not really a genre. It spans all genres, but has no allegiance to any. The Beatles, for example, were only a rock band until about "Rubber Soul". Then, they were something else; something which included baroque horn concertos, Hindustani classical music, and English children's folk songs. As a musician with an equally feverish love of Ella Fitzgerald, Joni Mitchell, Queen, and Prince, this approach strikes me as the ultimate expression of musical freedom, creativity, and playfulness.
But, in case you think "pop" is a dirty word, let me remind you that all of the aforementioned artists, PLUS Bob Dylan, had multiple hit songs. In other words: historically speaking, a lot of pop songs have been smart, soulful, well-crafted, and honest. I plan to make a few more of those.
Why Pleasure?
"We must risk delight. We must have the stubbornness to accept our gladness in the ruthless furnace of this world." - Jack Gilbert
I subscribe to the radical notion that pleasure is good for you (and for me, and for all of us). Pleasure is a source of joy, inspiration, connection and aliveness. It relaxes us, invigorates us, and re-connects us to ourselves and each other. I'm not talking about the shallow pleasure of Oreos and reality TV (not to knock either), but the deep-soul-pleasure of making love, night-time swimming, vigorous cuddling, and good, sweet, true music. 
For me, music is the ultimate hedonistic pursuit: I make it, and listen to it, and love it, just cus it feels so dang good. This is the attitude I'll be bringing into the studio; become a backer if you want to hear what I bring back out.
Photo by Bobby Bonsey
The Team
Besides the songs, I've got two weeks of scheduled studio time (in January), and a plan to attack this project with moxie and playfulness. But better yet, I've got a group of disgustingly talented musicians who are ready and willing to make this crazy thing happen.
Our merry band of pranksters includes: Pete Donnelly, founding member of The Figgs and producer of my 2009 record 'Buoy' (as well as many other excellent records); Joe Plowman, bassist extraordinaire, friend and collaborator since 2009; Pat Firth, NYC pianist and jazz/pop/R&B aficionado; and Jano Rix, world-class drummer/percussionist/vocalist/melodica player/salsa dancer.
These guys are talented. But not only that; they are silly. And smart. And committed. They know that the point is to feel good, and play with feeling. And between them, they can draw on a massive sea of musical references.
I am confident that with this crew, a lot of playfulness, and a little good luck, I can make anything I can imagine.
The Budget
Here is a more detailed breakdown of costs for my original ($29,500) goal.
 "Recording Costs" include:
Paying the producer and the musicians who play on the record.
Studio time, lodging, and food during the recording sessions.
"Design and Manufacturing" includes:
Printing CDs and pressing vinyl records.
Paying for cover art design.
"Kickstarter Costs" include:
Kickstarter takes a 5% fee from the funds collected.
Amazon payments takes another 3% for credit card processing.
My estimated expenses for Kickstarter rewards not included in other parts of the budget.
The Take-Home
Thank you, in advance, for every penny you're willing to part with. I am grateful every day for the people that make it possible for me to sit in my little pink studio (The Watermelon, pictured below) and write songs; or to hunker down with my favorite musicians and turn those songs into a record. 
I feel blessed and honored, 100% of the time, to make music. (Yes, even when I am cranky.) I love this work, and I love you for making it possible. I don't take this opportunity lightly (though I do, of course, take it playfully). 
I love you madly!
Carsie
Photo by Bobby Bonsey
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
I'll be the first to admit: good pop is hard to make. If it wasn't hard, there would be a lot more of it. It's hard to write a song that is true and good and bursting with hook and melody; but I believe I have a few up my sleeve. It's hard to create a delectable aural confection like "All You Need Is Love" or "You Send Me" or "Where Did Our Love Go?", but goldang it, I'm willing to try.

Other than that, my struggle (as always) is trying to operate respectably here in the material world. I will do my best to deliver all the rewards on time, and I will hire a helper or two to make that more likely. But, in case I'm late, I hope you'll follow Mary Oliver's advice about holding meetings with creative people: "If I have a meeting with you at three o'clock, rejoice if I am late." It means that the spirit of pop has possessed me, and she's not done with me yet.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

updates.update_content:
Hello, friends!
It's been a long five years since So Ferocious came out! 
I mean, looooooong.
I'm writing to let you know that I've made yet another album, and it's

Hello, esteemed backer! It's been almost exactly two years since I released So Ferocious, thanks to your generous and radical support.
And lo and behold, I just finished another album! 
It's called Buck Up, and it's about courage, chaos, and the incredible tenacity of desire. It's a story of disappointment and rage, in the personal and political realms, and finding the gumption to get out of bed and make the world a kinder, funnier, sexier place. 
You can read more about the inspiration behind Buck Up here.

campaign.story:
We're a group of designers and engineers who create cross-sensory experiences. 
Incubated as a collaborative art & technology project including residents of NEW INC at the New Museum of Contemporary Art, REIFY is a physical music platform that combines the best of both physical and digital music technology, and creates a new way to experience music.
REIFY transforms music into something you can hear, see and hold.
We make totems that visually represent an artist's song, and encode them with music and interactive visual experiences that you can play on your mobile phone or tablet. The mobile app used to play totems is called Stylus.
Totems are encoded with music and visuals that can be played back using the Stylus mobile app.
Our platform lets artists express their music in physical and visual form, and gives fans an interactive, multi-sensory experience that they can share with others. REIFY is a new medium of creative expression for artists, and a deeper, connected music experience for fans.
We've spent the last 9 months building and testing our platform in direct collaboration with musicians. Now we've partnered with a group of amazing artists on this Kickstarter to release their music on totems, to fans everywhere.
HEALTH, mae, YACHT and Tim Fain are REIFY early adopters designing totems for this Kickstarter.
Every totem can feel as unique as the song it represents.
                                                      Close up of a 3d printed PLA totem.
Close up of a 3d printed PLA totem.
Close up of a cast bronze totem.
We’ve designed hundreds of experimental totems for many different kinds of music. Through many beautiful trials and educational errors we've established an audio-to-physical design process where each totem can look and feel as unique as the song it represents...while remaining structurally sound.
We've prototyped our totem fabrication processes to find a balance between creative flexibility and lasting, physical objects. The rewards for this Kickstarter will be 3D printed in PLA plastic, with limited editions cast in bronze.
When not being used to experience music in a whole new way through the Stylus mobile app, each totem is also a beautiful stand-alone art object. Imagine having your favorite music live in your home as physical art you can hold, display and share.
Totems are also stand-alone art objects you can hold, display and share.
The opening scene of HEALTH's Dark Enough experience.
Our free Stylus player app will be available on iOS at public launch. We also have a functional Android version that we plan to get ready for public release late spring next year.
When a fan points their mobile device camera at a totem, the Stylus app plays back a music and interactive visual experience, also designed with the artist.
Each experience is unique in style and content. Some are game-like. Some are conceptual explorations. Others are both...and neither. All are direct expressions of the artist's creative vision.
Each totem experience is unique in style and content. This is an untouched real time capture of HEALTH's Dark Enough experience.
Another untouched live shot of HEALTH's Dark Enough experience.
Totem experiences can be incredibly detailed. These untouched real time shots were taken from a mobile camera about 4 inches away from the HEALTH Dark Enough totem.
Working with HEALTH to create a totem for their single, Dark Enough.
1. MAPPING
When we partner with an artist we first provide a range of visual interpretations of a specific song, in the form of abstract 3D models. These models are based on both the artist's creative goals and the automated mapping of various musical attributes to physical and visual ones by Harmony, our custom audio-to-physical engine and parametric design software.
2. DESIGN
Using these models as a starting point, we work with the artist to design a custom totem that matches their creative intentions and visual aesthetic. We also collaborate to create an interactive visual experience which includes and represents the song. The creative choices and decisions made for each totem are saved and learned by our system, and used to improve our generated Mapping models for every collaboration that comes after.
3. PRODUCTION
Once both are complete, we 3D print the totem and encode it with the experience using Unity and Vuforia. The combined experience of physical, audio and visual can take nearly any linear, exploratory or other form of narrative the artist wants to create for their fans.
4. RELEASE
Fans who purchase the totem and download our free Stylus app can play back the music and interactive visuals on their mobile device, experiencing the artist's song through sound, sight and touch.
Our Harmony software learns the creative choices made by each artist, improving every collaboration that comes after.
YACHT - "Music is by nature immaterial, but people need something to hold onto, to help make it feel concrete. Physical albums used to serve that purpose; the death of the physical album, in a way, opens up new possibilities beyond vinyl and acetate. We've always been interested in designing objects and experiences around our music, but REIFY's concept of a totem that embodies the sound itself is light-years ahead. We're early adopters."
HEALTH
mae - "Sometimes things aren't lost in translation, they are FOUND in translation. 100 years ago Wassily Kandinsky said that "The arts are encroaching one upon another, and from a proper use of this encroachment will rise the art that is truly monumental." Kandinsky used his paint to SHOW us music. Now, 100 years later, technology has given us the ability to SEE music in a new way yet again. REIFY is taking music beyond the realm of sound and into the realm of the multisensory aesthetic experience."
Tim Fain 
Ivy Ross, VP Google, Head of Glass - "I have been waiting to be able to not just live in rhythm, but to hold it in my hands. Reify ignites this new blending of the senses in a way that will provoke more questions then answers, which is the best part of our journey."
Jake Friedman, Manager/Co-Founder, We Are Free - "In this moment of 'on demand' everything, Reify has created a new physical format. And that format promises to return ritual and aura to recorded music. Who wouldn't be excited about that?"
Paste Magazine - "The swirling structures are artful representations that could just as easily be seen in your living room as in a museum."
Colossal - "Sound wave interpretations in your hands, as 3d-printed sculptures."
The Creator's Project - "Music becomes tactile and textured."
Bloomberg Business - "It's hard not to get excited about staring your favorite song right in the face."
The Wall Street Journal - "Shapes that can be printed and then played back with an app that divines the sound from a scan of the object made to represent it."
Teen Vogue - "How One Girl Turned Her Favorite Songs Into Sculptures with Computer Software"
The REIFY pins and stickers include an interactive visual you can play with the Stylus app!
We've been a self-funded full time project until now. We're beyond excited to be working with the musicians collaborating with us for this Kickstarter, and want to bring their totems and the Stylus app to music lovers everywhere.
We now have:
a beta version of our Harmony audio-to-physical design software
a beta version of the Stylus player app for iOS
tested fabrication processes and manufacturing partners
our first full totem + Stylus experience completed for HEALTH
a second wave of artists ready to release songs on totems in 2016
Use of funds: 
design & build totem + Stylus experiences for each Kickstarter artist 
custom package art for each artist's totem
back end development to get Stylus 1.0 ready for wide public release
hire a dedicated production manager for mass manufacturing and fulfillment
Allison and Kei met while residents of NEW INC, the New Museum of Contemporary Art’s design & technology incubator. They've been building the REIFY platform full time for the last 9 months.
Allison Wood
Allison Wood is REIFY’s co-creator and CEO. She has a background in art, design and technology. After studying sociology at Mount Holyoke College she moved to NYC where she worked in fashion with a focus in accessories. Her love for design, architecture and human interaction led her to pursue an MFA in interior design at Pratt Institute and a second MFA in digital interactive art, to explore how technology influences and shapes physical space. She went on to work for acclaimed artist Jamie Zigelbaum where she developed and produced large scale interactive works. She was a collaborator on 2014 Design Miami/ Basel Commission and a participant in the first Digital Art Auction at Phillips. In 2013 Allison co-created and became the CEO of REIFY. This year she presented REIFY at TEDxTeen and SxSW.
Kei Gowda
Kei Gowda is REIFY’s main tech guy. Before joining REIFY he spent 20 years building stuff like verbal-to-visual chat clients, connected fitness wearables, motion-based desktop interfaces, haptic VR controllers, predictive healthcare systems and UFC.com.
UX Design & classical piano: Christine Walthall
Community Outreach & keeping it real: Ruby Lawrence
Production & perfect hair: Zoe Camina
Interns: Stephanie Oppenheim, Brittany Johns
CO-CREATORS + ADVISORS
Before meeting Kei at NEW INC Allison interned for Ara Katz and Jamie Zigelbaum. It was with them she explored the early concepts of REIFY, together developing foundational ideas on the relationships between form, meaning and digital synesthesia that have influenced her work every since. It was with their support and encouragement that Allison applied to NEW INC and committed to REIFY as her full time pursuit.
Jamie Zigelbaum - MIT Media Lab, Dark Matter, Midnight Commercial
Ara Katz - MIT Media Lab, SpringNYC, Beachmint
ADVISORS
Ivy Ross - VP at Google, Art.com, Gap Inc, Harvard Business School
Michael Moskowitz - Global Chief Curator at eBay, Bureau of Trade, IDEO
Alex Olwal Ph.D. - Google, MIT Media Lab, KTH Royal Institute of Tech
Jake Friedman - We Are Free, Lovepump United Records
CONTACT
Questions? Comments? Cool! We're a small team that answers every correspondence personally. Drop us a note on the comments page or email us at  kickstarter@reify.nyc.
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
Sometimes the unexpected happens, and there are many things beyond our control. Suppliers may miss a deadline, a machine may start malfunctioning or a shipment can get lost. Those things can cause delays, Nevertheless, to minimize any setbacks and inconveniences, we are going to work with the most reliable suppliers, manufacturing plants and shipping agencies, to ensure you get your rewards by the intended delivery date.

DESIGN

The physical form for each artist's REIFY totem is designed by REIFY and that artist, using our custom software. The Stylus experiences for each totem are designed by REIFY, that artist and an digital artist versed in 3D motion graphics and working directly in Unity. 

HEALTH's totem and full Stylus experience are complete and ready to move to production. We've begun initial concepting and collobration with some of the other Kickstarter artists. 

Given the variable nature of any creative collaboration among multiple artists and designers, each full project may take different amounts of time and effort to reach production-ready designs. Potential delays to production could occur if design time extends past what we planned for.

MANUFACTURING

We're partnered with Voodoo manufacturing for 3D printed totems and a private bronze casting partner in NYC for the numbered edition totems. 

The HEALTH totem's manufacturing process has been tested and confirmed. Optimizing for production of that totem at scale is currently underway. Fabrication testing and optimization for the other artist's totems will depend on the complexity of the final physical designs, materials, etc.

We're working closely with Voodoo and our bronze partner, and using our experience from our work with HEALTH, to predict and remedy any manufacturing challenges before we move to mass production. Potential production delays could happen if an artist's desired design proves a high effort to fabricate, needs to be reworked for predictable printing or casting, etc.

PACKAGING AND FULFILLMENT

Our totems are to be packaged and fulfilled from a dedicated location in Brooklyn. Our design, manufacturing and packaging facilities are all within 1 mile of each other. We have sufficient storage space to fulfill at scale. 

We have a plan for fullment that requires a dedicated production management hire + knowing just what and where we're shipping all our rewards, in order to confirm our predications on effort and time for delivering rewards. Both will happen upon Kickstarter rewards successful funding our campaign.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

campaign.story:
We designed Seltzer to make it easier and less time-consuming to organize cooperatives. Unlike traditional CRMs, which are usually used by trained staff, Seltzer is designed to be simple and intuitive enough for all members to use, and reduces the amount of training needed for volunteers with limited time commitments. Over the past five years, groups like i3 Detroit have used Seltzer to grow to hundreds of members without needing paid staff. Now we're taking everything we've learned and building a secure, stable 1.0 release. Seltzer is Free and Open Source, so you'll always be able to download it, run it yourself, and contribute improvements. We also have some cool rewards for our backers!
Designs of the 2" laptop sticker and 1.5" "visa stamp" sticker
This campaign will fund several weeks of focused development time to work on improvements that are too big to do as side-projects: linked data support, REST API, modern single-page interface. The funds will also pay for server space to host a publicly accessible instance of Seltzer. Anyone will be able to use it to organize their publicly available data for free, and subscribers (or $100 backers) will be have the ability to restrict their data to certain groups or users. Of course, as free software, anyone can download and run their own private version with all the features!
What will Seltzer do?
Tracking membership status
Online dues payment
Tracking door access privileges
Coordinating mentorship
Coordinating volunteers
Secure handling of member complaints
Member contact and emergency contact info
Visualizing membership growth
What makes Seltzer different from other software?
Ease of use
Intuitive interface
Active community of users and developers
Track record of maintenance and support
Decentralized
Common core, specialized extensions
Linked open data
You can see the old version of the code here, but the new version will look very different!
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
Software development time can be difficult to predict. We will focus on the most widely-requested features at the beginning, and add further features as time permits. Our goal is develop a useful and stable application that will be easy to improve through open source collaboration. Backers can track our progress on the project's public code repository.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

Happy hacking,

Hi All,
First, thank you so much for pledging your support and messaging me with your excitement and questions. I'm extremely grateful to all of you. While the time may not be right for a new version of Seltzer, talking to people over the last few weeks has convinced me that a tool like this is needed, and that when the time is right, someone will make it happen. updates.update_content:
The relaunched Kickstarter is going well. For those who've renewed (and increased!) your pledges, thank you so much for your continued support. For the remaining, please help us finish strong by pledging today. I know it's a time of summer vacations and frustration from forgotten Kickstarter passwords. But less than a week remains and the clock is ticking.
The videographers and I meet often, and October interviews are being scheduled. Research has been in high gear for months. We're building a wiki into the film website and continue to collect amazing photos (and even a few early film clips) from the era. We already have enough material to make this a very comprehensive look at the history of preschool education, from Froebel's original plan for Kindergarten to the current state of affairs. But I need your help.

updates.update_userinfo: We're back on Kickstarter, please help us launch strong!
updates.update_content:
Thank you again for supporting our Kindergarten documentary project last month. The last 30 days have been very productive. Several sponsors have stepped up to cover the first half of our project goal offline. I've reduced the Kickstarter target down accordingly (and adjusted the pledge/reward amounts) in a newly launched project: https://www.kickstarter.com/projects/froebel/history-of-froebel-kindergarten-documentary-film
I hope you'll take a few minutes now to support the new project. Offline sponsorships saved us Kickstarter fees so the rewards list now contains a few Early Bird discounts specifically for the Froebel faithful who pledged last time ... but you need to act before they're gone.

In the interest of making a shorter Kickstarter video intro I neglected to explain our strategy for setting the budget and target film length. Here's that explanation:
We chose a small funding goal that gave us the maximum return/flexibility while setting the funding bar low to make the project most likely to succeed. The bulk of the proceeds will go to capturing interviews with experts/researchers. So many stories spin out of Froebel (toys, pedagogy, historical figures, American culture (e.g. "Happy Birthday"), art/architecture, design education, crystallography, MIT Media Lab and Shape Grammars, etc. that it seems most important to provide context and show how interwoven Froebel's work became. We can efficiently edit these story elements together so we can communicate (even in brief) to a wider audience ... especially potential funders of a longer film. When more funding is found we'll expand the  depth of these areas. But capturing the researcher interviews now is more urgent than completing a longer film.

campaign.story:
Arduboy is a new game system for classic games
Brilliant OLED Display
6 Soft-Touch Tactile Buttons
2 Channel Piezo Speaker
Durable Metal & Polycarbonate Construction
8+ Hour Battery Life & Rechargable
Fully Programmable with Arduino!
What is Arduboy?
Arduboy is an open platform for people to play, create and share games. A game system the size of a credit card. Choose your favorite classic game from the completely free Arduboy Arcade. Built on the popular Arduino software, it’s also an excellent way to learn how to program! Because you can learn to make your own games, Arduboy is a game system the size of your imagination!
Free Games!
Every game published on Arduboy Arcade will be free, open source and available to be edited. We have sent out over a hundred developer kits and here are a few titles the community has built and we are working on adapting to the platform:
Special thanks to the Arduino Gaming Community!! We are proud to join the party of open source gaming started by these awesome projects that pioneered the way to make and share games!
Hackvision
Gamebuino
TeamARG
Super Retro!
Designed to remind you of a more simple time in the world of gaming, the Arduboy brings true 8-bit gaming into the 21st century with style. The black and white screen invites you to involve your imagination once again while gaming.
Open Source Gaming!
Anyone can make games for the Arduboy! Free online tutorials guide you through a step by step process on how to develop your own software! There are already plenty of examples to learn from. Ever wanted to create a level or map for your favorite game, or make your favorite character jump higher? Now is your chance!
Education Kits!
We want to help you use Arduboy to teach kids how to program! What better way to engage young people in software development by giving them the power define their own game world? Children love to create, and Arduboy helps make creating games more fun and accessible than ever.
To encourage the use of Arduboy in classrooms we are offering an education kit reward that includes 10 Arduboys at the same price as our early bird units. But that’s not all we also will provide a printed booket and free online coursework for an entire lesson plan for learning C++ on the Arduboy!
Custom Branding!
Want an Arduboy like no other? 5 lucky backers can pledge for a batch to be produced with custom laser engraved artwork on the metal back, complete with a custom game we develop for you! If you want the coolest business card on the planet or are looking for the perfect promotional item for your business then this deal is for you!
High-Tech, Low-Cost!
Fitting the same dimensions of a credit card (85.60×53.98 mm), the Arduboy is built to be as thin as possible yet incredibly durable. We spent an entire year working out the best way to balance thickness, durability, practicality, and cost and we are very proud of this result. At only 5mm thick, we have achieved a device that can live in your pocket (or even wallet) thinner than any mobile phone! In the future we want to work to trim this down, but that will take a lot more work and a little bit of magic!
Specs:
Processor: ATmega32u4 (same as Arduino Leonardo & Micro)
Memory: 32KB Flash, 2.5KB RAM, 1KB EEPROM
Connectivity: USB 2.0 w/ built in HID profile
Inputs: 6 momentary tactile buttons
Outputs: 128x64 1Bit OLED, 2 Ch. Piezo Speaker & Blinky LED
Battery: 180 mAh Thin-Film Lithium Polymer
Programming: Codebender, Arduino IDE, GCC & AVRDude
A polycarbonate front, ultra thin circuit board, and stamped metal back gave us the ultimate combination. A rechargeable lithium polymer battery provides over 8 hours of battery life, and the same cable you use to charge can be used to upload new games!
Why Kickstarter?
We need your help to reach the final stages of manufacturing! For over a year we have been working on prototypes, learning about industrial design and manufacturing and we are finally ready to confidently say that this is a product we can produce for everyone!
But this is more than just about making a product... we want to build a strong community around creating and sharing games. A successful campaign will help us hire more game developers and spend more time creating even more awesome games by the time we ship!
Stretch Goals!
If you help us blow past our funding goal, here are a couple rewards we will make available to everyone!
The front cover of the Arduboy is clear polycarbonate so what gives it color is the circuit board itself. Before $50k we will produce Arduboy with a white PCB. After that we want to offer a full rainbow of colors! If we reach this goal, we will ask you in the kickstarter survey following the campaign what color you would like!
 If this campaign reaches a Quarter Million Dollars, we will unlock a limited number of Special Edition Gold Backed Arduboys! If you want to get the ultimate Arduboy, this one is for you! We will put some awesome custom laser engraving that signifies this comes directly from the Kickstarter campaign. This is the ONLY time we will ever make gold backed Arduboys!
Details on how to grab a Gold COLOR Arduboy are outlined in Update #5, so check it out there!
Thats right! If we get to the magic number of One Million Dollars - Kevin will change his name to Arduboy! This has been an incredible journey and along the way people have already started calling him by this name so let's make it official!
But realistically... that extra money is going to go to hiring extra software developers, working on the website, marketing, advertising, development of future products and all of the other things associated with growing a company... maybe Golden Arduboys?
Thank you for everything!
A year ago the original prototype Arduboy was featured on YouTube, thousands of people have emailed and commented about Arduboy. It’s only because of you and your support that we have made it this far. We hope to give back to the community as much as possible throughout this campaign and the business that continues after. Almost a year ago, the entire internet came together and showed me if you follow your dream, it’s possible to change the world. We want to give back that experience to you! So get your Arduboy today and play, make and share some awesome games!
Special thanks to the following supporters:
HAX for bringing me out to China and showing me how hardware is made!
Arduino for creating the hardware and software that taught me how to build my own electronics!
Adafruit for making it easy to buy and learn things to create awesome digital blinky lights!
Noel Joyce for helping with the industrial design
Bill McDonough for help with the mechanical engineering
Antony Bui for directing and filming the kickstarter video
Michael at Nootropic for creating one of the first handheld Arduino game systems out there
Rodot at Gamebuino for continuing to inspire me that there is a market for portable programming platforms
TeamARG for making some of the highest quality arduino games we have seen to date!
To all my friends and family for supporting me before the kickstarter!
Time-line

Who are we?
Kevin Bates - Founder
I posted a YouTube video a circuit board the shape of a business card playing a popular falling block puzzle game and the internet went crazy for it. I left my day job making 300 foot tall 2 million dollar wind turbines to make a pocket sized game system for less than $30.
Chris Martinez - Lead Software Developer
Likes to play video games. Likes dogs. Pretty simple guy really.
Ross Shoger - Community Manager
He has run several successful Minecraft servers and knows linux better than Kevin.
Advisors:
Jeremy Gordon - Former VP of Engineering for Twitter, previously head of game studios, hardcore hacker, really smart dude.
Duncan Turner - Former designer at IDEO. Makes sure Arduboy stays sexy.
Silent Partner - 20+ Year video game design veteran. Much mystery, very secrets, so intrigue… wow.
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
In life, there is no reward without some risk. No pain, no gain and all that jazz. However, an ounce of prevention is worth a pound of cure. Listed below are a few known challenges and risks and what we have done to mitigate them.

Component Sourcing:
When building a product comprised of multiple components, multiple vendors must be selected to provide all of the separate components. Wherever possible, we have used parts that are very common and can be manufactured by many different factories, and can be purchased in large quantities.

Design for Manufacture and Tooling:
We have spent the last year working directly with factories and changing the design to be easily produced and assembled. There is still a little more work to do in this area, but we are lucky that the Arduboy is a very simple product to produce.

Tolerances, Quality Control and Testing:
We have worked with several mechanical engineers with many years experience designing commercial products. We also have planned time to make last minute tweaks so there are no sacrifices made to quality!

Factories and Delivery Schedule:
We have pre-selected multiple factories for production of the Arduboy. We have agreed on the schedule and have already produced hundreds of developer kits to test their skills! Our schedule already accounts for the possibility of several delays and still be able to ship on time!
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter
