campaign.story:
I’ve wanted to bring the STEM careers message to kids through comics for a long time. I grew up as a math and science guy that loved comics and my dad taught me to read using comics. I know for a fact that comics work! Now that I have two children of my own I’ve worked to get my own kids interested in STEM. I did not find the existing materials to be very engaging. I am convinced that comics are a better way to getting this information into the hands of kids.
My dream is to eventually create a SERIES of these STEM career comics for kids. Each comic will focus on a STEM job and give some insight into what that job is like, what they would spend their days doing, and what kind of money they can make. Each story will show how a middle school kid became a STEM professional.  
REWARDS - In our reward section we describe a variety of packages that you can use to bring “David, Software Engineer” into your classroom, groups or communities. Our packages are designed to fit the needs of most school classrooms, groups and communities, but every situation is a bit different. If you’d like to describe your class, group or community size and composition we can recommend a package appropriate for you. Contact me at: pgamble422@att.net
STRETCH GOAL - Reaching the stretch goal of $25,000 will provide enough funding to do storyboarding, writing and preliminary art for a draft of a SECOND STEM Career Comic Book as we've done for "David, Software Engineer". All backers of $15 or more will be able to vote for the Stem Career of the 2nd Book through a short survey!!!!
Here is a list of possible careers for a second Stem Career Comic Book: Aerospace Engineer, Architect, Cellular Biologist, Civil Engineer, Electrical Engineer, Marine Scientist, Mathematician, Mechanical Engineer, Nuclear Engineer and Petroleum Technologist. Let us know what career you would suggest making into a 2nd book.
Kids need to know that the jobs that will allow them to live a life of their dreams are in the STEM fields. We need to draw a connection between their school efforts and their future lives…this is where communication has been failing between parents and children and teachers and students.
Unfortunately, the depicted parental lecture scene is happening all over the country.  Instead of lecturing your kid (again and again) my comic provides you with an alternative for getting STEM career-related information to your kids in a format they will listen to.
There are more forecasted STEM (science, technology, engineering and math) jobs then we have students in the pipeline. We know those jobs are among the highest paid.
Kids are losing interest in STEM (Science, Technology, Engineering and Math).
Kids continue to tell us they do not understand how math and science are relevant to their future. They want to know how that the Algebra I class they do not like impacts their future career and lifestyle. The lack of relevancy leads to disinterest, lack of motivation and decreased engagement.
Materials are needed that Engage, Stimulate Interest and Expose kids to STEM concepts and careers that focus on WIIFT (What's In It For Them).
But don’t take my word for it, check out some of the great feedback I have received from kids about the draft of my comic.
I loved comic books as a kid (and STILL Do!), and I realize that a better way to expose kids to STEM is through a series of comic books focused on STEM careers. 
I’ve been working on this idea for quite a while and have already made up two drafts of the comic.  I’d like to introduce you to "David, Software Engineer". 
David, like most other students, has no idea what he wants to be when he grows up. David is always messing around and fiddling with phones, calculators, and computers. His interests seem to be more on gadgets than actual studies and therefore throughout middle school and high school he gets tutored by a girl named Carlie. What he didn't realize was that if he just applied what knowledge he used with his gadgets and gizmos to everyday life, he would be just fine. While being tutored by Carlie, he realizes he likes her but is too shy to say so. Will David ever find out how he can better apply his unique skills towards his future? Will he ever get the courage to tell Carlie how he feels? 
In showing my first draft to kids I've got input that indicated I needed to make some changes for girls. I have modified the comic book so that it appeals to both Girls and Boys. The feedback has been positive from both boys and girls. We’re now ready to finish things up and move forward.
While the work of developing the comic book is nearly complete, we need your help to finish up "David, Software Engineer" and to build up a community interested in bringing the STEM careers message to students in comic book form. 
"David, Software Engineer" is different than other career-related materials in that:
1. It has an engaging story  
2. It uses graphic art to add to the "text" in the story  
3. It includes career-related information from the viewpoint of a young person
4. Maps the necessary skills, knowledge and attributes of a STEM career to specific middle and high school classes
Sample - Career-related content
I am also creating Educator, Student and Parent Guides to make the comic book a more effective educational tool.
The guides will focus on Vocabulary, Guided Discussion, Discussion Questions, Post Reading Activities, Character Analysis, Standards, Additional Activities, Knowledge Gained, Graphic Organizers and Guided Reading.
Student's Guide Sample Page
All of the educators that have reviewed the unfinished guides have commented on how helpful and useful they are.
By supporting this Kickstarter you are helping get "David, Software Engineer" into the hands of the audience it is designed for...KIDS!
Your support will allow me to do the following:  
1. Print and deliver comic books to parents with kids, schools and other organizations that serve youth to begin to make a DIFFERENCE  
2. Create and provide access to digital copies of the comic book for mobile devices  
3. Research and Identify another STEM career with a Female main character for a 2nd Comic Book 
4. Identify an audience for delivering career-related information about a STEM career in a comic book 
5. Collect feedback on how to Better the product moving forward
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
As with any project there are no guarantees. This project has three key areas of risk: content creation, delivery of promised rewards and communication.

Content creation - I have created drafts of the comic book. I understand the process of collaborating with writers/artists and making changes. 

Delivery of promised rewards - I have a background in project management and I am used to delivering things on a deadline. I am good at creating a schedule and following up to make sure things get done. 

Communication - A lack of communication can lead to unmanaged expectations and a poor relationship which will reflect poorly on the project. I am a good communicator and have a history of keeping everyone informed during any project I am a part of.

Should problems arise I will communicate the issue, the proposed solution and the time to correct.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

campaign.story:
The history of art commissions is the history of wealthy people paying artists to make something about wealthy people, or big institutions paying artists to make something about everybody else.
In 2015, we think that there’s a different way to do this — one in which anyone can contribute to a commission, to make art about everyone who contributes to it.
So this Kickstarter is the collective commission, not just to fund the work, but to become part of it. 
One pledge gets you four works of art, each produced with your data. 
In June, the artists will release four new works of art generated by this campaign's backers. This art show will be made available on the Internet, on Electric Objects' EO1, and at a real world event. 
200% of the funds will go directly to the artists. *
Because Electric Objects believes in supporting the creation of new art, we will match every dollar that's pledged to this campaign.
*up to $2,000. (We need to save some of our budget to fund other art projects @ Electric Objects.)
placesiveneverbeen.com
Addie's work explores the tension between expression and technology. She seeks to blend conceptual work with traditional forms of hacking and sculpture. 
Addie has shown at bitforms gallery, House of Electronic Arts Basel, and PARMER 
reas.com
Casey writes software to explore conditional systems as art. Through defining emergent networks and layered instructions, he has defined a unique area of visual experience that builds upon concrete art, conceptual art, experimental animation, and drawing.
Casey has shown at bitforms gallery, [DAM]Berlin, Rhizome
jamesgeorge.org
James applies computational photography towards portraiture and storytelling. Through installations and films he addresses the emotional response to science fiction technologies as they become reality. By sharing his code and processes openly, he enables others to express themselves using the techniques he develops.
James has shown at Ars Electronica, Sundance New Frontier, and XOXO Festival
lauren-mccarthy.com
Lauren's work explores the structures and systems of social interactions, identity, and self-representation, and the potential for technology to mediate, manipulate, and evolve these interactions. She is fascinated by the slightly uncomfortable moments when patterns are shifted, expectations are broken, and participants become aware of the system. 
Lauren has shown at NODE Festival, Eyebeam, and Ars Electronica.
Your pledge will produce four amazing, mind-blowing, never-before-seen projects. 
Share a common sky in real time
You provide your city/town with state or province.
A dynamic and collective portrait of everyone
You upload a selfie or a self-portrait photograph.
Every day is someone's birthday, and you deserve a present
You share your birthday plus an image of something you always wanted but could never have.
A continuous performance based on your likes, check-ins and tweets
You share your public Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, Foursquare profiles.
Because most of us have never commissioned art before, and it's a wonderful thing to do. There's a prevailing notion that commissioning art is a game for the wealthy, that it's out of reach for the rest of us, that the Art Market is something we can read about on the front page of the New York Times, but that we can't participate in. 
We think that's silly.
  Thanks
Last but not least, a very special thanks to our friends who helped make this campaign possible!

Video: Kristina Budelis
Editing: Sky Dylan-Robbins
Music: Benjamin Weiner

Good news everyone: We're launching The $5 Commission online next week!
On August 17th, The $5 Commission artworks will go live on the web. Addie, Casey, Lauren and James used your answers to the backer survey to create four original works of art. 
Check out our last update for a sneak peak of what's in store.

Thanks to everyone who came to the Private Preview of The $5 Commission Tuesday in Greenpoint! It was a fun evening, where we debuted four original works of art, commissioned by you and made with your data from the backer survey.

updates.update_content:
We did it! We are now over 1,000 backers, almost $7,000 in pledges and counting!
With a little over an hour to go we wanted to take this time to say a big thank you for supporting The $5 Commission. Our goal was to make commissioning art more accessible to more people, and we’re humbled to see so many of you get behind this project.

With 700 backers, over $4,500 raised, and less than 24 hours to go, we decided it's time to up the ante.
So here's the deal: If we reach 1,000 backers by the end of this campaign, we will give one lucky backer a free EO1 in June!

Wow! We're really humbled that over 500 of you have backed The $5 Commission in just 24 hours. We have now raised over $3,300 to fund the creation of new work (660%+ funded)! Thank you to all the backers and friends who are helping to make this project a reality.

campaign.story:
So many possibilities! Makes an amazing holiday season gift!
Incorporate Build Upons into the latest Star Wars spaceships!
 We are Lunchbox Electronics and we are creating Build Upons: Light up bricks to build upon your existing LEGO® creations.  Light up your robot, house, or spaceship! Our Build Upons are based on the smallest 1x1 brick we could fit an LED into to create elegant and flexible designs. The Build Upons system has three types of bricks: an LED brick, a power brick, and a bridge brick. 
You can power an LED brick by stacking it directly on top of a power brick, or use the bridge brick to route power to LEDs throughout your design, allowing LEDs to be placed anywhere! 
This 3D printed prototype shows an LED brick stacked on a bridge brick stacked on a power brick.
The bridge bricks allow for flexibility within the design. The below examples use the bridge bricks to route power from the battery pack to the LED bricks, wherever the LED bricks happen to be. The bridge bricks function even when turned 90 degrees!
Build a Helicopter!
These are only a few of the projects that highlight our bricks, we can't wait to see what you do!
We have created these prototype bricks, but we need you to get to a production run!
                                                         Specs and Process
This product will be released as open source hardware upon shipping! Trust us - Alicia wrote the book on it.
We are using standard surface mount white LEDs in the bricks powered by a 4.5v battery pack. AA batteries not included. The bricks have metal running through the top and bottom creating connections where they stack. We have gone through several prototyped designs, improving each one. 
Here is a walk through of our design changes in R&D.
Each iteration reflects a change to make our product more manufacturable and easy to assemble. We are now in our fourth major design iteration and ready for production. The earliest prototype was done with 3D printing, copper tape, and inserting LEDs into a plastic brick by hand, which was time consuming and tedious. In order to build lots of these bricks we need to invest in injection molding. 
The Team
This was the only photo that Puppet had her eyes open.
 *Alicia Gibb* Alicia Gibb is the CEO of Lunchbox Electronics. She has been playing with LEGO® her whole life, but started research on lighting them up in 2007. Alicia has a Masters in Information Science, focusing on physical computing and interaction design. She is also the founder and Executive Director of the Open Source Hardware Association (OSHWA), an organization to educate and promote building and using open source hardware and wrote Building Open Source Hardware. She is a member of NYCResistor, founded and co-chaired two Open Hardware Summits and directs the Blow Things Up Lab at University of Colorado Boulder. Her work has appeared in Wired magazine, IEEE Spectrum, Hackaday and the New York Times. 
*Jason Brownstein* Jason Brownstein is the Mechanical Engineer of Lunchbox Electronics. He has also been playing with LEGO® his entire life! He graduated from the University of Colorado Boulder with a Masters in Mechanical Engineering. Jason has prior experience with product design, manufacturing, and design and fabrication of interactive art. Building things to withstand all human conditions is his jam. On any given day you can find him playing with the 3D printer, on the phone with manufacturers, making 3D models, or cuddling baby bunnies.
*Puppet* Puppet is the Marketing Director and Customer Service at Lunchbox Electronics. She has been doing comedic relief all her life. Puppet has an honorary PhD in Antics and Tomfoolery. Talking in a high pitched voice is what she does best. She is also Jason's boss when Alicia is out. 
*Our Networks* Our team spreads farther than just who sits in the office everyday. We leverage advice and learn from notable figureheads within the hardware and electronics communities including Nathan Seidle of Sparkfun Electronics, Eric Schweikardt of Modular Robotics, Amanda Williams of Fabule Fabrications, Kipp Bradford of KippKitts, our friends at Sketching in Hardware, and all the friends at NCYResistor.
Help Us Spread the Word!
Every tweet and share will help us reach our goal and go above and beyond! 
Timeline
We are set up to begin manufacturing. We've gone through several iterations and prototypes already and are confident that we are ready to mass produce this product. We aim to have the kits out by Christmas 2015! These will be the prefect gift for LEGO® aficionados!
Lunchbox Electronics Timeline
2012 - First prototype designed!
2013 - Nesting design completely changed to the the Basket design
2014 - Copper design changed to incorporate 90 degree turns
2014 - Build Upons PTH (plated through-hole) version manufactured. Designed for use in printed circuit boards but also compatible with LEGO®. Fit and feel has been proven to be perfect!
2015 - Ready to begin manufacturing of Build Upons
When we ship the project's source will be released as open source hardware! 
Budget
We have already done the R&D to get through the initial prototyping costs: 3D printing, PCBs, and an initial proof of concept for tooling. We will be using multiple sets of tooling including die casting and injection molding to achieve the finished product. We are planning to cover the non-reoccuring project costs with our Kickstarter as injection molding is the most expensive part of our project.
Help Us Spread the Word!
Every tweet and share will help us reach our goal and go above and beyond!
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
The risks and challenges of any hardware project is in the manufacturing. We already have manufacturers lined up for this product who specialize in precision manufacturing and are confident they can achieve the tolerances needed for a good fit. There are often delays with hardware, but we believe we've found manufacturers who are prepared to create our designs and work through changes quickly and effectively. They are responsive to our design changes, give great feedback and work well with us. We have already manufactured a less complicated through-hole LED brick as a trial run: http://www.lunchboxelectronics.com/product/build-upons-pth-edition. Manufacturing the previous brick allowed us to prove that we could create interlocking bricks compatible with LEGO®. Our current challenges are the cost of injection molding and die casting, but that's where you come in! 

LEGO® is a trademark of the LEGO® Group, which does not sponsor, authorize or endorse this project or web site.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

campaign.story:
Welcome to Pants for Makey Makey.
Pants is an acrylic and neoprene case for your Makey Makey. 
Acrylic and Neoprene awesome.
Pants for Makey Makey got started as a request for Makey Makey cases to be deployed in an educational environment.
The only existing Makey Makey cases came from overseas, with long delays and high shipping costs.  So I designed Pants for Makey Makey.
Pants CAD
Pants come in varied colors, and provide instant tactile engagement with your Makey Makey.  Different back-plates fit Makey Makey versions (1.2, 1.1, or 1.0).
Pants for Makey Makey is an open source project. The plans to laser-cut or 3d-print Pants will be released on the completion of the Kickstarter project, whether it succeeds or not.  
Why? Because small bits of plastic shouldn't be shipped half-way around the world. Release will be CC-BY-SA 2.0. Commercial use is allowed and encouraged.
Custom Spacers for Pin headers.
Pants for Makey Makey features:
Easy access to Makey Makey pads and pins.
Flexible neoprene gasket.
Lock nuts that stay in place. Not sharp.
Custom 3D printed NinjaFlex spacers.
Rounded corners. Not sharp.
Competitive $14 price.
Made in the USA.
Open Source Plans. Laser Cut (DXF) and 3d Printing(STL).
*Makey Makey and NinjaFlex trademarks are property of their respective owners.
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
Risks:

The first Pants have already been produced. So no risks in design setbacks or unforeseen manufacturing difficulties.

Production delays are unlikely since the Pants are being manufactured locally by myself through my company Danger Laser LLC.

Danger Laser uses a 100-watt CamFive laser cutting machine to rapidly produce the Pants frontplate and backplate.

The custom NinjaFlex spacers are 3d printed on my Replicator 1 3D printer. This is surprisingly fast due to the small size of the spacers. 1000 sets of (4) spacers 3d print in as little as 75 hours. 

I have two backup 3d printers in the event of a printer failure.


Timetable:

The acrylic is sourced through Eplastics. Eplastics ships in 1-3 business days. With standard shipping we should receive the plastic within 14 days of the end of the Kickstarter.

If for some reason certain colors become unavailable, the colors may be subject to change or variation.

The neoprene sheet is sourced through Seattle Fabrics. With standard shipping we should receive the neoprene within 14 days of the end of the Kickstarter.

The shipping will be handled via USPS flat rate boxes. There is an extra dollar in shipping to cover tape, boxes, bubble-wrap, labels, etc.

Pants is a limited run. There is no danger of astronomical numbers being backed because of the limited number of each reward. If you don't get your Pants now, don't despair. Pants will be released open source so you can make your own.

Based on this timetable, Pants for Makey Makey will ship in April.

I will continue to make very small improvements to Pants until the Kickstarter campaign is complete.

If you like Pants for Makey Makey, please pledge your support!
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

campaign.story:
STEM SLAM was designed by high school science teacher and instructional coach Dr. Ramsey Musallam. Frustrated with the lack of opportunities for scientific exploration present in the traditional classroom environment, in 2008 Ramsey began hosting summer science camps for Bay Area youth designed to transcend traditional curriculum and expose students to the wonders of inquiry. STEM SLAM weekends have emerged from Ramsey's original ethos, but aim to provide young minds with a chance to explore a specific area of interest during the regular school year. 

After a weekend of cutting edge exploration removed from paradigm of traditional schooling, participants will return to their respective classrooms with a kit of materials and associated lesson plans in hand ready to empower their peers and teacher(s). The connection between the excitement of a STEM SLAM weekend, and the immediate sharing of a student's experience with their classroom teacher(s), is integral to STEM SLAM'S mission: To  promote a love for science in all young minds that transcends the classroom, while simultaneously helping to empower and transform the traditional classroom environment. 
Program Specifics 
Fundraising Rational: Initial funds will go towards securing a consistent location, weekend facilitators, various high-end materials spanning a diverse range of activities/STEM content domains, participant take-home kits, and a low-participation fee to attract a high number of curious participants. 
Time Frame: Four self-contained weekend "slams" 1/month, that may be taken in sequence, or individually. Weekend "slams" will occur every month during the normally scheduled school year (September - June).
Tentative Weekend Topics (note: topics are flexible and will likely change and develop as resources are gathered and feedback is obtained)
Weekend 1: Circuits
Weekend 2: Robotics
Weekend 3: Biotechnology
Weekend 4: Forensics
Content: STEM SLAM activities include, but are not limited to: 
building and soldering circuit boards.
designing remote control devices for land and air robots.
creating robotic drone air shows. 
programming autonomous robots.
prototyping and designing wearable technology.
exploring the chemistry of explosives. 
leveraging chemistry to solve mysteries. 
Sample Weekend Scope and Sequence 
Day 1: Circuit Construction 
Part 1. Exploring electrical resistance using conductive and non-conductive dough and ink. 
Part 2. Soldering as a method of building circuit boards.
Part 3. Construction of a circuit board that uses conductive and non-conductive materials to play musical tones of varying frequencies.
Part 4. Musical instrument invention using constructed circuit board and re-purposed conductive and non-conductive materials. 
Day 2: Circuit Application 
Part 1. Development of robot remote control circuit board that repurposes conductive and non-conductive materials. 
Part 2. Construction and connection of robot to developed circuit board.
Part 3. Control of robot using circuit board to accomplish a variety of tasks. 
Part 4. Task invention that leverages developed remote control and autonomous robotic functions. 
Program Sustainability: Each STEM SLAM participant will be given a kit that includes a myriad of materials and activity guides to share with their peers and teachers. Follow up between the STEM SLAM staff and classroom teachers will occur, and subsequent classroom adventures and creations will be shared with the world via stemslam.org. 
More information: http://www.stemslam.org
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
Risks associated with STEM SLAM fall into two categories: safety and accountability. Regarding safety, participants will be engaging in various activities that involve strict attention to safety such soldering circuits and handling chemicals. From an accountability perspective, although every effort will be taken to establish a strong line of communication between STEM SLAM participants, and their classroom teacher, satisfying the mission statement above is highly dependent on participant and teacher follow through. 

Challenges associated with STEM SLAM fall into two categories as well: location and materials. While the activities associated with STEM SLAM are mobile and can implemented in a myriad of locations that offer power and open indoor/outdoor space, securing and reserving a consistent location will be a challenge. From a materials perspective, because STEM SLAM aims to provide students with a "cutting edge" experience in science, it is inevitable that materials harnessed will be updated frequently as newer and more advanced systems are released.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

campaign.story:
Reserve yours today to be able to buy more later on SparkFun.com!
The Qduino Mini is perfect to embed in your electronics projects, it's super small, inexpensive, has a battery connector & charger built-in, & a fuel gauge that can tell you when to charge the battery!
 "I have a favorite project" - John Dimatos, Tech Curator at Kickstarter, on Bloomberg Radio 
Tell me more:
The Qduino Mini can tell when your project runs out of juice - with an integrated battery monitor / fuel gauge
The Qduino Mini is Arduino-compatible & 100% open source, hardware and software meaning that making and programming your first circuit is a breeze.  Hardware is hard, so we decided to make it a little bit easier.  The day that the first Qduino Mini ships, all of the design files, including EAGLE board files, schematic, and code will be released under an open source license.  Here's what it includes:
The Qduino Mini has an integrated battery charger
Battery Charger Circuit - just plug in USB and it charges the battery with the auto switching circuit - there's no extra charger needed & no digging the battery out of your project so you can charge & program at the same time over USB!
Battery Fuel Gauge - guessing on when your project runs out of juice?  We've got you covered - we have a simple monitor library for your battery so you can remind yourself when it needs a little extra juice.
Ultra small, Ultra thin, Ultra light - The Qduino Mini itself is 1in x 1.5in (2.6cm x 3.9cm) & 0.18oz (5 grams), perfect for quadcopters, drones or high altitude balloon projects.  Both the Qduino Mini and the batteries (LiPos) used to power the board fit are super compact & thin, just right for embedding in your projects.
What can you make with the Qduino Mini?
Prototype your projects with the Qtechknow Creator Kit!
 Tech Specs:
ATmega32U4 Processor - Arduino Leonardo Compatible
32KB Flash Storage
2.5KB SRAM
1KB EEPROM
3.3V @ 8MHz
20 Digital I/O // 14 Dedicated
12 Analog Channels // 6 Dedicated
7 Digital I/O also PWM channels
SPI, I2C, UART available
LED Indicators for: ON, Charge Status, TX, RX, D13
TPS78233 3.3V 150mA Regulator
MCP73832 LiPo Battery Charger
MAX17048 LiPo Battery Fuel Gauge
Charge a battery while it's inside of your project!
Power Your Project:
LiPos are rechargeable, super thin, and extremely light, and are based on the Polymer Lithium Ion chemistry.  You'll never have to take the LiPo out of your project - just plug in USB power to charge the battery.  The LiPo's run at 3.7V, safe for any application.  No more wasting AA batteries - these LiPos are rated for hundreds of uses.
The charging time for the LiPo's is around 1 - 2 hours, depending on how large the battery is.
How are prototypes going?
15+ fully functional Qduino Minis
Arduino Sketches loaded over USB
All I/O Pins & Analog Pins Tested
UART, I2C, SPI functional
Charging Circuit working with 3.7V LiPo Batteries
Battery Fuel Gauge successfully reading LiPo Battery %
We are now working on perfecting the fuel gauge, more testing, and creating the online tutorials and firmware.
Manufacturing:
We are super excited to be teaming up with SparkFun Electronics, our sole manufacturer for this Kickstarter campaign.  They will manufacture, program, & test the boards and fulfill the backer rewards.  They have fulfilled over 11,000 MaKey MaKey Kickstarter Rewards and almost 7,000 MicroView Backer Rewards on time.
Nathan Seidle (CEO of SparkFun Electronics) has been a great mentor to me and has helped me engineer the Qduino Mini for the past year.  I've known SparkFun for more than 3 years & they are awesome people to work with - they are ready to produce the Qduino Mini.  They also proudly support Open Source Hardware.  The bulk of SparkFun's products are environmentally safe & RoHS compliant.
The Qduino Mini's parts will be sourced from the USA and China, but all will be manufactured at SparkFun HQ in the USA.
Shipping:
The Qduino Mini will be shipped from SparkFun in the USA (Niwot, Colorado).  Shipping anywhere in the USA is an additional $5 per pledge.
- All shipping methods (domestic and international) are tracked -
International shipping is an additional $24 per pledge.  We ship internationally to most countries, and all international customers are responsible for import fees.  We cannot ship to: Iran, Cuba, North Korea, Sudan, Syria, Brazil, and Russia.
Note: LiPos are not included because of shipping restrictions in any reward level, except for the Qtechknow Creator Kit.
Note: Headers are not included in any of the reward levels, except for the Qtechknow Creator Kit (which has female headers soldered on to allow quicker learning).
Here's our proposed timeline:
What will we do with the money?
The $12,500 of funds from the Kickstarter will help us:
Kickstart our project of Qduino Mini's & keep the project going
Order all of the parts in bulk from the USA and China, to get the costs down
Marketing
Make the current prototype perfect for production
Safety testing for the charger circuit and battery monitor
Online tutorials to get started with the Qduino Mini
About Us:
Quin Etnyre of Qtechknow discovered electronics by reading Make Magazine and attending his first Maker Faire Bay Area in 2011. He has taught himself Arduino, taken classes and has had excellent engineering, business, and design mentors including Nathan Seidle and Jeff Branson of Sparkfun, Bob Martin of Atmel, and Diego Porqueras of Deezmaker 3D Printers and Hackerspace. He started his own business, Qtechknow in 2012, which features ArduSensors, a line of fun and educational kits that he developed to empower anyone to experiment with electronics, regardless of age, background or skill level. He strongly believes in the power of open source hardware, and all his projects are open source. He teaches adults and kids in his “Intro to Arduino” classes, has 28 Instructables published with 470,000+ views, maintains his own website and store at Qtechknow.com, was featured in Popular Science, Make Magazine, & the BBC and has presented his projects at Maker Faires around the world including the White House Maker Faire in 2014.  He is 14.
Website / Store: qtechknow.com
  Media Contact:  Quin Etnyre - 14 years old, CEO Qtechknow
- info@qtechknow.com
Credits:
Music - Biblio - Lovers' Carvings (Haugli's Mix)
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
One of the most common challenges in hardware Kickstarter campaigns is manufacturing. Our component manufacturers, PCB manufacturers, and assemblers all are in the US, or China. SparkFun Electronics, our sole manufacturer, has over 10 years of experience in engineering, manufacturing, and order fulfillment.

Although I am 14, I have the full backing of my parents. My PCBs and development boards have been reviewed by expert engineers from SparkFun Electronics. All Qduino Minis have been tested over and over, and are all safe & high quality products.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

campaign.story:
Company Mission & Ethos
At Endorfin Chocolat, our mission is to awaken the senses of chocolate lovers worldwide by opening them up to the innate potential of "the food of the gods." Our products unite ancient alchemical formulations and flavors with modern technology and craftsmanship, resulting in mouthwatering chocolates that are timeless and satisfying to the soul. We believe that our chocolate is some of the healthiest available on the market today, based on our commitment to organic and sustainable farming and wild-harvesting practices, the origin of our unique unroasted heirloom cacao, low-glycemic sweeteners, and the diverse selection of exotic botanicals and supplements we infuse into our products. As a modern social enterprise, we invest our profits into local communities and projects, with a special interest in preserving the legacies of the people and communities that have made it possible for you to enjoy the botanicals, spices, and cacao we use to make our modern vintage chocolates.
For this Kickstarter campaign, we are raising a portion of the money we need to invest in new packaging that will allow us to put our best chocolate bars on the shelves at local grocery stores, along with some new equipment that we need to help us meet current production demands.
In my own words... 
This Kickstarter will really help me take the company to the next stage in our evolution. I'll be using the funds raised here for two separate needs that the company currently has - packaging and equipment. For our packaging, I am committed to using 100% recyclable and/or compostable materials that are ethically and sustainably manufactured. To make these ethics meet the reality of our business needs, we'll need to purchase and print our packaging in bulk, which will require a significant initial investment. So while the initial costs will be high, we'll be able to maintain our ethics, keep the costs of our bars lower, and pass along these savings to everyone who purchases them from a grocery store or local market. Additionally, we'll need a more efficient tempering machine to mold our bars and enrobe our truffles, which will allow us to further decrease our production costs - a savings that we will again be passing along to all of our fans. In the end, I hope to produce chocolates that are ethically sourced, as healthy & nutritious as possible, and made with the highest quality ingredients available today, all while maintaining an affordable price point for our fans. I really hope to make the world a better place with every chocolate I produce, from the cacao growers, to our environmentally-friendly packaging, to one day being able to use the profits of the company to support ecolgical stewardship and human rights efforts related to our mission. By supporting this Kickstarter, you'll help us make our ethics meet the reality of business, and get some absolutely amazing chocolates in return. Every contribution you make will help secure a more sustainable future for our small, mission-driven company. Words can't express how much I'd rather pay it forward in chocolate to you and your loved ones instead of paying outrageous interest on loans to corporate banks that could care less about our guiding ethics. 
Thank you for helping me take this dream to the next level! 
Mr. Brian Wallace  
Chocolate Alchemist 
Founder of Endorfin Chocolat & Community Supported Chocolate
--------
FAQ
Ingredients/Allergens
Our chocolates are naturally free of dairy, soy, gluten, GMO, artificial flavors, and refined sugars. As such, our chocolates are safe for many folks with dietary restrictions and preferences. We do occasionally use nuts in our recipes and on our equipment, and all of our chocolates are sweetened with coconut sugar, so if you have a sensitivity to nuts our chocolate might not be for you.
Shipping
Shipping to all 50 states & Puerto Rice are included with all contribution levels. We'll be shipping out via USPS Priority Mail once the project is fully funded. All packages will arrive within 2-5 business days after that - with plenty of time to make it for the holidays. To have us send directly to someone as a gift, just put their shipping address in during the checkout process. If you'd like to include a small gift tag with a personal note, just let us know what you'd like it to say in the comments field during checkout!
Sharing/Spreading the Word
Please share this page with your friends! Write an email, post on Facebook, Twitter, or Instagram, or whatever you like! If you can help us get the word out by any other forms of media and would like our support, let us know!
Have another question or comment?
Drop us a line at orders@endorfinchocolat.com and we'll get you taken care of as soon as we can.
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
The biggest potential challenge we'll have in this project is if it surpasses the funding goal several times over! While we're currently producing backstock to prepare for all of our holiday orders and what we'll have to fulfill from this Kickstarter, if this things gets big we might have a hard time keeping up with production demands with the current equipment we're using. To prevent this from becoming an issue, we've built in extra time between when the Kickstarter is over and when we'll have to ship to get everything delivered on time for the holidays. If the Kickstarter surpasses our goals, we've built in this extra time to give us a little cushion on doing the extra production work necessary to pull everything together in time.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

campaign.story:
Austin Tinkering School was born 5 years ago, in the backyard of our East Austin home.  Inspired by the Tinkering School started by Gever Tulley in the Bay Area (check out his TED talk here), we saw a need and opportunity to inspire the next generation of ATX Makers, hackers, and inventors. Austin has always been a haven for the DIYers, craftivists, tech-savvy innovators, and think-outside-the-box-ers and we needed a school that not only could teach skills but provide access to space, tools, and materials so kids and adults could design, build, create, as well as strengthen their ability to problem solve, collaborate, and innovate.  
Anyway, here we are, 5 years later.  We've built go-carts, roller coasters, pinball machines, tree forts, hovercrafts, 2 story waterslides, and countless other projects both big and small.   We've offered classes in arduino, robotics, raspberry pi, and 3D printing.  We've had guest Makers teach classes in enameling, video game design, concrete casting, soap making, and lots more.  We even started the Austin Mini Maker Faire (now in it's 4th year), which is a two-day, family-friendly event to MAKE, create, craft, learn, play, invent, and be inspired.  So let's just say we are ALL about the Making.
And we are SO ready to move out of the backyard and into a centrally located, community oriented, kid- and family-friendly Makerspace!  We want to bring these meaningful hands-on Maker experiences to more kids and adults all over Austin.  We also need a Tinkermobile (a truck with a dedicated set of tools and locking tool boxes) so that we can more easily bring tinkering projects to schools, rec centers, afterschool programs, churches, events, and everywhere that kids are found.  
We would like to find a warehouse, old auto repair shop, or other industrial space with a fenced-in side yard (kids need playspace and room to build big) for around $2000 a month.  The amount of funding we are attempting to raise will provide us with a $1000 per month towards rent for one year , which will ease our financial situation considerably, and will allow us to establish ourselves at the new location.  $4000 to spend on a used truck for our Tinkermobile would be fantastic.  The remainder would go towards Kickstarter fees and expenses, as well as remodeling of our new space, signage, and a few new tools.
And Boy Howdy yes do we have stretch goals!
$1000 for a welding set-up 
$2100 for a Blacktooth Laser Cutter 
$2000 for additional computers and software 
$1000 for a kiln
$2200 for a Makerbot Replicator 2 3d printer
$5000 for a desktop Shopbot
$5000 would enable us to buy a stepvan and to create a more complete Tinkermobile.
$12,000 for another year in the new space!
Kids love tinkering.  Tinkering is a great way to learn.  Through tinkering kids are empowered and inspired!  The Maker movement is booming, and Austin has NO Makerspace that is specifically for kids (and lots of other cities do already).  Let's do this, ATX!  Help us Make a Makerspace for us all!
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
We are actively seeking a suitable space and hope to find something that works for us in the next few months. We have had enough possibilities in our price range that we believe that we'll be able to find something that in the next few months. Most importantly we hope to find something before summer camp season. If we are unable to find a new home for Austin Tinkering School by the end of 2015, we will use the money to create a program that will bring tinkering classes, programs, and experiences to underserved youth. We have plans to create this program either way, but if we are not able to secure a space, we will put our full energy into this program.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

updates.update_userinfo: A new home for Austin Tinkering School!

updates.update_content: Only 4 hours left!  Just wanted to mention that our Month of Making reward for $20 is going to be really fun.  Starting on Nov. 28th/Black Friday, you'll receive awesome projects and ideas galore from guest makers like Bernadette Noll of , Kate Payne from , Samantha Matalone Cook of , as well as a healthy helping of hot tips from yours truly at Austin Tinkering School, delivered piping hot to your inbox every morning for the next 30 days. Kids projects, bath/body/home/hearth, food, gifts, and lots more! Set a precedent to Make this holiday season!

We hit our goal, AND EXCEEDED IT!  This is amazing!  We now have enough $$$ to create a welding set-up, which we've never been able to offer before.  This is going to expand our capabilities astronomically.  And while we're at it, why not keep going and go for a LASER?

I woke up this morning, still 3 thousand dollars away from our goal with only 35 hours to go.  SO close but still so far!  I took my dog for a walk, and when I got back, Boing Boing had written a post about our campaign, a SuperStar friend had chipped in for the mega Nerdy Derby experience, and we rode the wave all the way to our goal, and past it!  COWABUNGA!! 
Our campaign ends tomorrow, Nov. 25th at 8 pm.  We've still got some pretty cool stretch goals we'd love to hit, while we're at it.  A welding set-up, a laser cutter, more computers and software, a new 3D printer, a CNC machine, and a kiln would be super nifty new tools that we would use like crazy!  We'll get them sooner or later, but sooner would be pretty awesome :)

We've still got lots of fun rewards left.   Snap up a few for gifts, or get that birthday party squared away, and feel extra good about it, because you are helping bring the first kid-friendly Makerspace to Austin, TX!  It's the gift that keeps on giving (or, er, tinkering)!
BIRTHDAY PARTIES: $300

Though it may be pure folly (considering we are still 6 thou away from our goal, and our Kickstarter ends in only 3.5 short days!) we have commenced a huntin' for a new home for Austin Tinkering School. A lot of those primo (to us) spots are out of our price range, but at least once or twice a week we come across something that's almost (but not quite) right... so that makes us feel like sooner or later, we're going to find a place that works.  Here are a few of the most recent contenders, if you're curious...

updates.update_userinfo: Austin Tinkering School T-shirt: special Kickstarter edition!
More kids need to grow up tinkering. Here are some reasons why.
updates.update_content:
This great article, My Role in De-skilling the Arts, by J.E. Johnson, the Scenic Studio Supervisor at University of Texas, makes a compelling case that kids are growing up with less and less exposure to the industrial arts, and it is having a negative impact: 
"Compared to those who came into our shop ten or fifteen years ago I can expect most of the students I meet this year to be less “handy.” They will have less dexterity, less of an eye for craft, and considerably less knowledge of tools and materials. Astonishingly, many of them will have never worked with their hands at all. For years the running joke has been that we teach students which way to hold a hammer – last year we had our first student who had never held a hammer before. Not funny."
PLAY

campaign.story:
I need your help to build a Piece of ART/Science. A twin Musical Tesla coil Electric Chair Guillotine. The purpose of this piece is to inspire a local group of friends and Artisans that ART can be Kickstarted, The purpose is too also inspire the young and old to study electricity and electronics.
The Main areas of design emphasis are:
(1) Safety.
(2) Two functional midi controlled Tesla Coils that play Music.
(3) Beautifully Crafted Electric Chair Prop
(4) Portability 
The majority of the project budget is utilized in addressing (1)the Portability,and Safety of the system, and (2)the actual Solid State Tesla Coils. 
Portable is good! The main issues with running the "Chair" at multiple venues (Residential/ Commercial) is (1) The Location of the power source vs. the location of the "Chair" and  (2) The Outlet Type of the Power Source.
Well, (1) Power source location in the majority of circumstances can be found with in 100 feet. This budget allows for a 100 foot 220v extension Chord, and a another 100 foot 120v extension chord.
(2) Power Source Outlet type can vary widely. This budget allows for 10 heavy duty patch chords to adapt to the 10 most common 220v outlet types.
The Safety budget allows for GFCI Breakers, Kill switches, and remote operation of power relays.
The actual Chair Prop portion of the budget goes towards providing the fabrication and finishing of the "Chair" prop itself, Trust me, this thing is going to look Old, "Authentic", and Scary Functional! The chair needs love and attention to  details such as wiring, lighting, painting, distressing, reinforcing. This thing is going to look like quote "Not only is it going to electrocute the guy in the chair, it's gonna get the guy throwing the switch!"
The actual coils will be purchased from OneTesla.com , a Kickstarted Tesla Coil company.They will be Midi Interfaced.
To sum it all up I hope this is one of the first of many Kickstarter projects that helps teach,  inspire, and maybe even lead the day to a Merritt Island/Cocoa Beach makerspace.
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
My number (1) risk to navigate is the inverted mounting and operation of the actual Tesla Coil themselves. the detail of this part will not be filled in until a OneTesla coil is in hand. I will be rely heavily upon a friend and associate of mine who was raised in electronics and is a very capable Electrical/Product Design/Engineer. Number (2) will be isolating and sheilding electronics from HF electricity, for ex. I hope to be able to use a raspberry Pi and camera for photos from the "Chairs" point of view. This will definitely need much attention. 

I also imagine delivering rewards "On Time" is always a potenial spot for risk if you are depending on other vendors for things like shirts and stickers. Fortunately vendors for such products seem to be readily available.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

campaign.story:
BlinkyTile: Build Your Own Dynamic Light Sculptures
When we received our first BlinkyTile prototypes, we were carried away by the visceral experience of creating both shape and light at the same time. We've made a lot of cool projects since we created BlinkyTape last year, but this is without a doubt our favorite. 
Each BlinkyTile has one individually controllable, multi-color LED, and the solder pads form both the physical and electrical connections between the lights. They can be soldered together to form any shape you can imagine. Recreate example designs, like our dodecahedron lamp or ring light, or set out on your own to build something amazing and unique!
Each set of BlinkyTiles comes with a controller programmed with several special light animation modes to make your project look awesome. But it’s not a one-trick pony: this controller will also connect to pattern editor software that allows you to easily make your own animations in a simple drawing program. Our software will even let you create sound-reactive sculptures!
Features
Supports hundreds of individually-addressable tiles 
Single USB connector for power and control - just like BlinkyTape!
Make patterns easily with the graphical pattern editor!
Or program your own - powered by the same chips as Arduino™ boards
Open Source Hardware - for total control and infinite possibilities.
Did we mention ¡¡¡¡¡RGB LEDs!!!!! ????
Sample Projects
Dodecahedron Lamp
 Ring Light
Free-Form Sculpture
About the Rewards
 Basic Pack
The basic includes everything you need to build the dodecahedron lamp or ring light: 14 tiles, the control board, and a USB cable for power. Just solder it together and power up, and you’re ready to go!
Use this pack to make one Dodecahedron or Ring Light:
Plus Pack
Got an idea for a bigger sculpture? The Plus Pack includes everything from the basic pack, plus 28 more tiles. 
Use this pack to make an excellent Free-Form Sculpture!
Explorer's Pack
If even that expanded set of possibilities isn't enough, you might be interested in the Explorer's Pack. Only for the boldest digital creators, you can use this selection to turn your wildest light-sculpture visions into reality. It includes 126 tiles, and everything else you might need, including control boards and USB cables.
With this pack, the only limit is your imagination!!!
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
Managing a project of this size can be a challenge. We've applying everything we learned during the BlinkyTape Kickstarter to the BlinkyTile, and have brought in expert collaborators to help where we found deficiencies. We've designed the BlinkyTile from the beginning with manufacturability in mind. 

The key areas of focus are:

Design: We've been rapidly iterating on designs over the past few months, starting with BlinkyTile's first appearance in Hong Kong and continuing to the big debut at the World Maker Faire in New York.

Manufacturing: We're producing the BlinkyTile with a manufacturer that we've been working closely with for the past year. We've already produced an Engineering Pilot (EP) run.

Fulfillment: Now that we've shipped thousands of BlinkyTapes to all corners of the world, we've had a chance to prove out a number of different shipping and fulfillment strategies. We've learned some hilarious things. For example: the German post office won't deliver packages if you don't address it to a proper name!

Support: Every Blinkinlabs product comes with full support, including instruction documentation and a community support forum. And we answer email!
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

updates.update_content:
Hey all!
It's been a little while since we posted an update and we have some good stuff to share.  After a strong finish, we've made the switch to full production mode! And, better yet, we can report some great headway.
Controllers

Hi everyone!
We're down to the final days of the Kickstarter campaign, and things are starting to pick up speed! Here's what we've been up to in the past few weeks.
Pattern Mapping Demo
Here's something we're excited to share: a demonstration of a sculpture that we've mapped out in software. This allows different kinds of effects, including the waves of darkness and light shown here:

Hi blinky friends!
This has been a really exciting week, and thanks to you we're now over 200% funded! That means we'll be able to dedicate even more resources to improving the design, documentation and software tools. We've had some great coverage of the campaign at BoingBoing, the Make: Blog, and Hackaday, however we'd appreciate any help getting the word out!

Well, we had quite the weekend.
In addition to introducing the BlinkyTile at World Maker Faire New York (and winning not one, not two, but THREE Editor's Choice Ribbons!) we hit our funding goal in just under 12 hours.
That's awesome. To everyone who backed us, shared our campaign page, or even read through the page and really considered backing us: thank you, thank you, thank you.  This kind of response really keeps us going, in every sense.

campaign.story:
Lakota Omniciye ("a gathering, assembly") is our Native American student organization here at Black Hills State University; although its members are primarily Native American, we encourage all students to join! This organization promotes fellowship among Indian and non-Indian students, and organizes an annual Cultural Awareness Week and Wacipi (pow-wow) in early April that is now in its 32nd year. In past years, the Wacipi has attracted as many as 3,500 persons, making it one of the larger pow-wows in South Dakota.
The powwow is the largest event put on by Lakota Omniciye, the usual cost of the powwow is about $22,000; In order to raise money for this event we have Indian Taco Sales every other wednesday, and collect raffle items throughout the year to sell. Sometimes we do sales for holidays like Valentines Day! These events are all organized solely by the students, including the powwow. 
I would like to raise money to make star quilts that I can donate to our student organization, in order to start raising money for this years powwow, which will be held in April 2015.
Please check out my link so you can get a feel for what our event is like!
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
The only challenges there will be is making the rewards! I will be working extra hard to get my backers their rewards, but it may take some time and I hope that you all will be patient and understanding in this time.

campaign.story:
If you've ever studied music history, you probably know that musical instruments don't simply spring forth from the music community fully formed. Much like people, musical instruments evolve over time. Sometimes these evolutions are the result of changes in musical styles, and sometimes they are the cause of them. And either way, it's hard to imagine an instrument that is more in need of a radical change than the DJ's turntable.
Yes, there have been some changes to the turntable since it started being used as a musical instrument, but these changes still adhere to the same basic design -- a design which, let's face it, was never meant for cutting and scratching. Turntables are fragile and sensitive; that delicate needle sits precariously in the groove and bounces around with the slightest jostling. Scratching is incredibly difficult and frustrating.  Now it's certainly true that the things that make musical instruments difficult are sometimes the very things that give them their signature sound. But in the case of turntablism, I think that an easier user interface could open up a galaxy of sonic possibilities. Imagine instantly alternating between parallel playlists, or creating layers of sound by using each of your hands to do the work of a separate DJ. Imagine routing a singer's microphone into a device that lets you scratch with live audio in near-real time!
Over the past few years, I've been developing the specifications for a more versatile and intuitive way to scratch, without the latency of digital or the fragility of vinyl. Your donations will be used to hire a product design firm to build a functional prototype of my device, which I'm calling The ScrubBoard. With The ScrubBoard, you scratch by moving a slider up and down a track, much like how you'd move the sliders on a standard mixing board. But the ScrubBoard's slider doesn't adjust volume levels; instead, it's internally attached to a movable tape head that makes contact with a strip of audio tape inside the device. As you move the slider, the tape head moves up and down the tape, thus generating a true analog scratch.
An important part of the turntable arts is the DJ’s use of a switch or fader to rhythmically mute and un-mute the audio from the turntable. This is commonly referred to as “cutting.” With the ScrubBoard, you achieve this effect by using a two-fingered push-button that sits atop the slider. I call it the Seesaw Killswitch, because pressing down on one side makes the other side come up. When either side is pressed down, the audio is un-muted. When it’s in the “halfway position” (with neither side all the way down) the audio is muted. Users can open and close the audio signal by alternately pressing with their index and middle fingers, and they can grasp the slider with their other fingers, thus allowing them to cut and scratch with the same hand.
Pressing either side of the Seesaw Killswitch all the way down un-mutes the audio.
So why would you want to cut and scratch with the same hand? Because you can use a second ScrubBoard with your other hand! With two ScrubBoards, a skilled scratcher could create a pretty impressive interlocking, polyphonic sound that would be impossible using traditional equipment, even with two people. After all, two musicians will never be as perfectly in sync as your own two hands are with each other.
While the Seesaw’s halfway position always has the effect of muting the audio, the effects of pressing down the right and left sides can be customized.  That's because the ScrubBoard uses the audio tape's four tracks to create two stereo playlists that run alongside each other, and it uses a dual crossfader system to route the audio to the two sides of the Seesaw.  Adjust Crossfader 1 to determine which playlist you’ll hear when pressing down the left side of the Seesaw.  Adjust Crossfader 2 to determine which playlist you’ll hear when pressing down the right side.  
Keeping both crossfaders on the same side allows you to double your cutting speed with one playlist. Keeping them on opposite sides allows you to instantly seesaw between the two playlists. 
At this point, you may have noticed a problem with all of this: Movable tape heads might be great for scratching, but turntablists do more than just scratch. A big part of turntablism is the controlled use of the turntable motor's automatic rotation. In other words, sometimes you need to just let the record spin.  So for straight playback, The ScrubBoard makes use of a motorized tape loop.  But unlike a standard tape loop, this loop uses a conveyor-belt design so that the play head is able to slide up and down the slider track without losing contact with the tape.
The "conveyor-belt" tape loop
The audio tape is mounted to the center of a loop belt, which is held taught by two rubber rollers. The loop belt has a writable surface, so users can hand-label all the transient audio events and then follow their movement as the loop belt turns.
To preserve one-handed functionality, the controls for the loop belt transport are on the slider. While grasping the slider’s base with your pinky, ring finger, and thumb, you can control the loop belt transport by twisting the grips on the base. Twist them to the left, and the loop belt will roll forward. Twist to the right and the loop belt will roll backward.
Notice how the user is interacting with the orange grips on the slider's base.
The grips will snap back to a neutral position and the belt will stop rolling when you stop twisting them. You can change the speed at which the belt rolls by adjusting the IPS control, which is above the crossfaders.
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
If my fundraiser is successful, I'll be working with the Bay Area product design firm Connekt, LLC, which will handle the CAD modeling, electrical engineering, and the manufacture of a working prototype. Because the ScrubBoard has not yet been engineered, Connekt could not give me an exact estimate for the manufacturing phase, so instead they have given me a "not to exceed" figure, which is the basis for my fundraising goal. This means I'll likely have leftover funds to reinvest in the ScrubBoard after the prototype is complete. But it is also possible that manufacturing will cost more than expected. If this is the case, I will sacrifice some of the ScrubBoard's functionality to keep costs down. That being said, Connekt, LLC has a solid reputation for providing quality, cost-effective design services, and I have every confidence that they will be able to complete my project within the budget they've indicated.

This prototype is meant to demonstrate the core concepts of the ScrubBoard, and as such will not feature all of the functionality mentioned in the promotional materials, regardless of whether there are budget concerns. The "ScrubBoard Guitar" attachment (mentioned in the video) will probably not be included. Also, the loop belt will not be housed in a removable cart, but instead will be permanently built into the console.

For more info on Connekt, LLC:
http://connektllc.com/

updates.update_content:
To all of you who have generously supported this project, I'm very excited to reveal what I've been working on since the campaign ended.  I'm dropping two new videos that show off some new features I've added to the ScrubBoard.  I've built a more functional rocker, which not only allows for DJ-style "crab cuts," but also allows me to alternate between two different audio signals.  And I'm happy to report that this has opened up a whole world of possibilities!  Check it out:
Video 1: Dual Playlist Scratching

First, I'd like to thank everyone who supported my ScrubBoard campaign. Thank you!!  Next, I'd like to assure you that the dream is not dead.  I knew from the get go that a tech campaign with no real deliverables was going to have a pretty slim chance of reaching its goal.  But I've always said that my main goal was just to get the idea out there and see if there was any interest, and by that measure I think it's been a smashing success.
My next priority now that the KS is over is to put together a cheap DIY ScrubBoard kit, so people can build their own "Alpha model" at home, but the ScrubBoard has several other prospects on the horizon as well.  A camera crew from CNET will be coming to my house this week to film me demoing an updated version of my Alpha model.  I've also been talking to a tech company about making ScrubBoard-related apps.  I'm certain that it will only be a matter of time before all this interest translates into a real deliverable that you can use at home.  So if you want to be the first to know when things happen, please subscribe to the newsletter:

Regarding the newsletter in my previous update: There's now a newsletter signup form on the ScrubBoard website:
http://jeremyseanbell.com/scrubboard/newsletter.html

updates.update_userinfo: Please send me your email address!
updates.update_content:
I've got a lot of plans for the ScrubBoard, and I'd love to keep you posted as things develop. Even if my KS campaign doesn't reach its goal, there are several exciting prospects in the works, including a possible DIY kit. So if you want to be in the loop, send me a KS message with your email address.
Thanks for your support!

updates.update_content:
I'm happy to announce that I did something that I should have done a long time ago: I bought the domain name thescrubboard.com .  I'm so relieved that it was still available!  The website is the same; it's just an easier to remember URL.  Actually, there is one addition: I added an "articles" page, which has links to all the ScrubBoard-related articles I could find online.  So far, I've found thirteen.  If you know of any other articles that aren't on the list, please let me know and I'll add them.
I also just created a Facebook page for the ScrubBoard -- something else I probably should have done a long time ago!  ... if you love it, go "like" it!
If you'd like to follow me on Facebook, I'll be posting occasional updates about the ScrubBoard.

On the 20th, I'll be doing an interview about the ScrubBoard for an online talk show called "The Slam Show."
http://www.theslamshow.com

Many of you have asked if I could add some less expensive backer rewards, and as they say on Kickstarter, the backer is always right!  New rewards have been added; go check em out!
And while you're at it, check out this article I found on synthtopia:

campaign.story:
Five Mile Mountain Distillery
Let’s face it people- whiskey has been part of our nation’s history since the beginning, and moonshine is a deep-rooted ingredient in the mix that is Floyd County, Virginia.
Old timers from these parts tell stories of hills so covered in moonshiner’s fires that they resembled fireflies rising out of the meadows on a summer night. And how they would back their cars all the way up the windy one lane road of Five Mile Mountain to load their trunks with whiskey so they could barrel through the brigades of police cars coming to break up the party. Here in Floyd County, the stories of moonshining, either making it or running it, are as rich as the historic vein of Appalachian music that pulses through Floyd—and we are proud of it!
We will be Floyd’s first distillery since prohibition. We plan on using the same old recipes with traditional copper stills on open flames. Our batches of whiskey are handcrafted and kept small so we can ensure our product is known for the same quality as our predecessors.
Where is the distillery?
The building that Five Mile Mountain Distillery resides in began its life as the Floyd County Public Service Authority (PSA). It was built right after World War II. The building pumped water from Dodds Creek before treating it and sending it on to the town’s water tower, where it was then gravity fed to both Floyd’s businesses and residences. As the town grew, wells were drilled to facilitate the increasing need for water and in 1976 the old water works building was closed. It remained vacant and deteriorated slowly until July of 2013 when it was purchased and repurposed for the distillery.
With great determination and lots of blood and sweat, life was brought back into this beautiful old structure. Renovating this rustic building was a very odd task due to the removal of thousands of gallons of water, thousands of pounds of steel and cast iron pipe, and very old, hard concrete. We feel as though all our hard work was well worth it to save such a unique piece of Floyd’s history.
Where will the money go?
Your money will be used to help us take the next steps to create a distillery in Floyd, VA.  The funds will be put towards buying all the necessary costly equipment for the distillery to run…legally!
With the funds raised, we will use them to purchase: 
Mash Tanks $800
Chiller $3000
Bottler $1000
Labeler $1000
Transfer Pump $1000
Proofing Tank $1500
Stainless Steel Barrels $2000
Additional items needed if we raise more than $10,000
Hot Water Heaters, Hoses, Compressor
For more on Five Mile Mountain Distillery and what we're up to, check out our website and Facebook page.
From all of us here at Five Mile Mountain Distillery, thank you for your help!

Rewards
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
This is the boring (but important) part…in order to manufacture spirits, we have to obtain permits from the federal government and the state of Virginia. Each of these has its own challenges and requires the distillery to be at a different phase in the construction or operations phase. This means lots of red tape because producing alcohol is a really big deal! However, we do have cause to celebrate because we received our federal permit in December 2013. Cheers to that! Now the challenge is buying all the costly equipment to get up and running!

campaign.story:
What is Looking Glass & Volumetric Printing?
Looking Glass is the world's first volumetric printing service.  We developed volumetric printing over the past year so that we could bring any 3D scene from digital space into the real world in magazine-resolution color.  A bioluminescent jellyfish. An amoeba magnified 100X. A boa constrictor consuming an elephant. 
This isn't likely something you've seen in 3D object printing or holography before.  Volumetric 3D scenes in millions of colors with full opacity and transparency control are now possible.  Meaning for the first time ever we can volumetrically print a thunderstorm you can hold, with the lightning visible through the clouds. 
If you can dream it, now you can hold it in a Looking Glass. 
Take this translucent frog, for instance (available as one of the Rewards for this Kickstarter).
Translucent Frog Looking Glass, modified by T.Y.F.
Looks like a real frog specimen in a box, doesn't it?  Perhaps caught and clarified in the marshes of Cameroon?  Ah, but don't let your eyes deceive you - we wouldn't be so cruel.  Get ready for a mind-blow.  There's actually no frog in that box.
It's just ink.  It's made up of hundreds of sheets of lucite, each printed with a tiny slice of the 3D modelled frog, complete with see-through skin and internal skeleton. When those slices are stacked, put into a vacuum chamber, and injected with a refractive index-matching fluid, the result is a volumetrically printed Looking Glass.
Reward Choices (NEW CURIOSITIES!)
And now we want to make volumetric printing available to all of you.  By backing our project, you will receive one or more of the world's first volumetric prints. Choose from any of the Looking Glasses below.
We've already unlocked twelve Looking Glasses, each available in three sizes.  And backers can now vote on unlocking the 13th Curiosity from the list below:
Detail on Each Unlocked Curiosity
CT-SCANNED HUMAN FOOT
This is the first, and thus far only, volumetric print ever made directly from a medical CT scan. Lisfranc injury. Dislocation of 2nd through 5th metatarsals.  Scanned two hours after injury in Manhattan. And now, dear backers, it can be yours!

BOA CONSTRICTOR DIGESTING AN ELEPHANT
This Looking Glass is an ode to one of our favorite books, The Little Prince.  When 6 years old, the author explains how he embarked on a career to become a magnificent painter with his first ever drawing: a boa constrictor digesting an elephant. However, when he showed his drawing to the grown-ups, they could not see a boa constrictor or an elephant - all they could see was a hat.  They promptly recommended to the author that he pursue another career path.
This Looking Glass is for the non-grown-ups out there.  From afar, it will look like a three-dimensional hat.  But when held up to the light, its true nature will be revealed - as a realistic boa constrictor with an elephant in his belly, as if caught mid-digestion in the jungle and preserved in lucite.

TRANSLUCENT FROG WITH SKELETON
A see-through frog with fully visible skeleton that looks insanely realistic.  But we've got to tell you - and I hope you're sitting down - there's no frog in that box.  It's just ink.  This is one of the first Looking Glasses we made with transparency.

INTERNAL HUMAN ORGANS
by Dr. Scott Camazine
This is a realistic drawing of the full internal organs of a human by fellow Kickstarter creator Scott Camazine.  The lungs are a bit translucent, demonstrating one of the new effects possible with volumetric printing.
CT-SCANNED POCKET PISTOL
Volumetric print of a CT-scanned Williamson Deringer pocket pistol, data provided by the University of Huddersfield.  Thanks to Dr. Paul Bills and James Williamson for opening up micro CT-scanning to volumetric printing.
POISONOUS MUSHROOMS
Fly Amanita (Amanita muscaria) is called the world's most famous mushroom or sometimes "The Fairy Tale Mushroom", thanks to its super powers in Mario Bros.  In real life however, it is deadly. 
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Amanita_muscaria_UK.JPG
But don't fear - we will 3D model an accurate volumetric specimen of a couple Amanita muscaria mushrooms which will pose no danger to life or limb -  unless mistaken for a 1up mushroom and ingested. 
CT-SCANNED DOLPHIN SKULL
by Dr. Scott Camazine
Another one from fellow Kickstarter creator Scott Camazine, this is a CT-scanned dolphin skull to be printed into a Looking Glass in full 3D volumetric glory. That being said, if you choose this Curiosity and you tell your friends it's an alien skull discovered off the coast of Florida, we won't say anything.
CT-SCANNED HUMAN SKULL WITH ILLUSTRATED BRAIN
by Dr. Scott Camazine
We were told by more than one backer that a Cabinet of Curiosities wouldn't be complete without a human skull.  So, for those backers we've tried to do something special - this is a Looking Glass based on a genuine CT-scan of a human skull down to the shoulders. All of the bone imagery is very much real volumetric X-ray data. (The brain imagery isn't "real" but it is an excellent 3D illustration, positioned correctly within the CT-scanned bone structure)
PICKLED SHARK (NEW!)
by Peter Tan a.k.a. Mr. How
One of the first experimental volumetric prints we made in 2013, this volumetric print was so realistic we often were asked, "Wow, how hard was it to 3D scan a live shark?!".  It's actually based on a drawn 3D digital model but does look freakishly real.  And now, the artist Peter Tan has made his Pickled Shark available as a choice for all backers. 
Coincidentally, these pieces happen to be volumetrically scaled in pricing to a certain life-size $12 million stuffed shark.
THE WORLD'S MOST TYPICAL PERSON OF THE 21st CENTURY (THEORETICALLY)
As reported in TIME magazine, the world's most typical person is a 28-year-old Chinese man.   
http://newsfeed.time.com/2011/03/04/just-8-999-999-like-him/
"He’s a guy, he’s Han Chinese, he is 28 years old and there are 8,999,999 others out there that look a lot like him. The image [above] is a composite created by merging pictures of 190.000 men that the Chinese Academy of Sciences collected over the course of a decade of individuals who fit that description"
BIOLUMINESCENT MOON JELLYFISH (NEW!)
Backers recently voted on unlocking this new Curiosity, the Bioluminescent Moon Jelly Fish.  Now we're in the midst of testing different luminescent inks which we will hand-screen on key areas of the jellyfish tentacles and body after the main volumetric stack is printed.
FLORIDIAN THUNDERSTORM (NEW!)
Details coming soon....!  (we are working on getting our hands on genuine volumetric thunderstorm data before we model this up)
Size Guide
Why we need your help.
Inspired by work we'd done on efficient micro-solar panels and a lifelong desire to make a walk-around full-color room-light-viewable hologram (or something like it), we've spent the last year transforming volumetric printing from hundreds of glass prototypes with machine oil into something magical.
If this Kickstarter campaign is successful we will be able to transform our prototype system into a full production volumetric printer capable of printing different size Looking Glasses in millions of colors.  We'll also be able to collaborate with (and pay) several of our artist and scientist friends making the amazing specimens you see in the cabinet of curiosities above. 
Thank you to everyone who is joining us on this adventure to build a new field of volumetric imaging. 
To the future!
Shawn, Christina, Alex, Angus, Samtim, Alvin, & Prachi and the dozens of scientists, inventors, engineers, designers, artists, and balloon clowns that helped us along the way.
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
Our team at Looking Glass has been in the invention business (first in cleantech, now in volumetric imaging) for nearly 10 years and we've experienced firsthand many of the delays that arise when bringing a new hardware technology to the world. Anything new isn't going to come into the world without a fight and a bit of screaming, even for the most experienced teams. This rule applies to both inventions and babies.

But knowing what's coming has given us a chance to prepare, to lessen the risk of delays associated with this first Looking Glass Kickstarter campaign. 

Most importantly, our fundamental volumetric printing tech already exists. It's no longer experimental - it's real, having been refined over the past year. In the lead-up to this Kickstarter, we've created hundreds of volumetric prints to refine both our process, hardware, and software.

Even so, we're pushing the technology to a new level for backers - we're upgrading to new suppliers of the input materials, transforming our prototype printer into a production volumetric printer, and adding a couple new Looking Glass sizes. We're confident we know how to manage the risks associated with these improvements, but we're human. And of course there's always a chance a microscopic black hole spontaneously forms at the center of Earth and consumes all life and Kickstarter rewards.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

updates.update_content:
Hello volumetric print backers from the deep past!!
When we ran this Kickstarter back in 2014 and you supported the creation of static volumetric prints, it was my dream that one day the ink in these prints would be replaced with light.  That the world inside of the volumetric print would come alive and move.
I thought it might take 10 years to go from the prints to something like a volumetric display that was dynamic and alive.
