updates.update_content:
Happy Friday!
We started putting together short (weekly) webisodes using footage that won't make it to the final cut of the film (we have over 300 hours of footage!). It's just a taste of what's to come in 2014, a taste of what YOU have helped us achieve: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RzG0xVSLdgw
This first episode takes place in Amherst, MA one month before the journey begins. We watch as Co-Cyclers Megan and Katie prepare their bikes for the many miles ahead.

Check out our first To The Moon poster! We’re still here working away and can’t wait to share the gifts of summer with you in the midst of this cold winter. Speaking of gifts, we have not forgotten about the rest of your donation rewards! They will be coming your way later this year. Thank you for your continued support and don’t forget to keep up with us on our Facebook and Twitter! Webisodes, more photos and updates coming your way very soon!

there is one month to go, over a thousand miles to cycle, and a whole lot of co-ops to visit! we are so proud of this project and incredibly grateful for the lessons that the past two months have gifted us. we have filmed the big climbs, the flat plains, the mosquitoes, the hottest heat waves as well as the struggles and insights that each of us have encountered. co-cycle is unlike anything else. It has changed the way we think about filmmaking, our future and ourselves. this is education in action. thank you for your ongoing support! we could not have done this without you!

Co-Cycle and the To The Moon film crew have made it half way across the country! Although we still have half the country and months of post-production ahead, it is apparent in the incredible footage and experience that this is and will continue to be a huge success. We could not have done it without each one of you, THANK YOU! 
You can learn more about what it is like making a film on the road for three months by visiting the director's blog: http://venaver.tumblr.com/
director emma thatcher will be blogging from the road! you can follow her journey here: venaver.tumblr.com

It has been a long journey but we have reached our goal. We cannot be more grateful for all of your generous donations! Your support, financial and otherwise, has meant the world to us. 
We will be sure to make your proud.Keep spreading the word and we will keep pedaling on. 
THANK YOU AGAIN!

Before heading off to California to prepare for the launch the crew has been spending their time in Amherst with the co-cycle team. 
With only 13 days left in our fundraising we have reached over 1/3 of our goal! Thanks to all who have helped us ride further down our path! Help us stay on track and spread the word.

Director, Emma Thatcher's most recent work Enséñame Cuba. Check it out! 
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wV-26lA_j9M&feature=youtu.be
check out our first video update!!

campaign.story:
***UPDATE***
We have been overwhelmed by the response to this project!  It has far surpassed our expectations.  And now we'd like to take it even further.  A few days ago we received an inspiring comment: 
Darien Gee 5 days ago:
Maybe you should set a new goal -- hit 15k and add the last two states! Will take you to lunch if you actually pull it off and make it to Hawaii (Big Island)!
We decided that it would be totally amazing to send a postcard from every state -- not just the lower 48.  It won't be easy because we'll have to bring the printer(s) with us and rent a car / figure out accommodations in two places but we think it would be well worth it.
If we get to $15,000 then we're headed to Alaska and Hawaii!  Everyone who has pledged $100 will receive those cards included in their 50 -- and we'll be able to send a postcard from every single state in the US!
Two photographers on the road for three months want to send you a self-printed postcard from every single one of the 48 states we pass through.
THIS KICKSTARTER WILL FUND THE PRODUCTION OF POSTCARDS -- NOT OUR TRIP!  WE'VE ALREADY SAVED UP!
It was all decided over pancakes at IHOP.  On June 1st, we would leave on a three month trip covering each of the lower 48 states. Three months prior to this conversation, we didn’t even know each other.  Now we’re going to spend countless hours in a very small space together, exploring as much of the country as we can.
We're both photographers and will be shooting a ton as we go -- and we'd love to share all the things we encounter and experience along the way with as many people as possible.
We created a website that tracks our location with photo updates and developed this postcard project in response to everyone who asked that we send them something or wished they could come along.  We hope this will let you take part in the journey with us, as it unfolds.
The postcards will be produced entirely in each state as we go -- we'll take a picture of something decidedly awesome, print the postcards, and take them to a post-office to send them.  You'll know where it's from based on the postmark, and we might include the occasional handwritten message too.
We've been saving up and planning for this trip -- we're ready to go June 1st no matter what.  We're doing the Kickstarter to cover the cost of a printer, paper, ink, and postage.  It breaks down to $2 a postcard.  They'll be printed on acid-free heavyweight card stock -- suitable for archiving and framing.  We'd both definitely sign up for this if someone else was doing it!
Hopefully you're as excited about this as we are. 
For more info, check out GOING NOWHERE.
You can also look at our online portfolios to get a feel for our work:
Andrew Kenney
Jake Jones
Andrew Kenney + Jake Jones
(here's what the postcards will look like)

updates.update_content:
Hey Everyone,
We know it's important that you can tell where the cards are from and have heard from many of you that the cards aren't clearly postmarked.  Once we have sent out all of the postcards and everyone has received them, we plan on producing a comprehensive guide with more information about each card.  We'll tell you about when and where they were taken, and include the story behind each as well.

Hey Everyone, 
Our project is officially under way and most of your first postcards are starting to roll in. We hope you guys are enjoying receiving these glimpses from our travels as much as we enjoy sending them to you. 
We’ve knocked out 3 states so far (New Jersey, Delaware, and Pennsylvania) and we’re off to Connecticut this morning. We’ve already encountered so many amazing things and people and we hope that this is only a taste of things to come as we continue our long and magnificent journey.

We just wanted to take a second to inform you of a few new ways that you can follow us along our trip and see more photos from our travels:

First and foremost, you should definitely check out our website at (). There you will find daily updates with extra photos that we want to show everyone, along with commentary from each location.

We’ve also set up an Instagram (@weregoingnowhere) where we’re posting photos from our phones to show you our day-to-day life.

There is a Facebook page as well:

Thank you all again for helping make this project happen!

Andrew and Jake

Hey everyone!
We are very excited to get out on the road and make this happen.  We've tested our printing setup and are very happy with the quality of the postcards we'll be producing.  The cards look and feel great.  Of course they will become a little weathered en route to you, but that's part of the whole thing.

Now we need your information!  It's important for us to get it as quickly as possible so that we can get organized in time.  Please give us your name and address, and if you have any special requests (states, messages, whatever!) let us know and we will do our best to accomodate them.  (you will be receiving a survey from Kickstarter very soon).

We have been overwhelmed by the response to this project!  Thank you so much to everyone who has backed so far.  It has far surpassed our expectations.  And now we'd like to take it even further.  A few days ago we received an inspiring comment: 
Darien Gee 5 days ago:
Maybe you should set a new goal -- hit 15k and add the last two states! Will take you to lunch if you actually pull it off and make it to Hawaii (Big Island)!

Thank you to everyone who has backed this project so far!  We are excited and just really happy about the support so far.  Can't wait to make this thing happen.
Attention international backers!  We WILL send postcards to you!  The fee per card is slightly higher to deal with the increased postage rate.  There is a new pledge option:
***INTERNATIONAL OPTION***

campaign.story:
Since Hurricane Katrina, the number of vacant housing units in New Orleans has doubled, raising the number of unoccupied houses to more than a quarter of the city's total units. It is an inescapable reality of life here, and lasting improvement is hard to see through: some owners fled the city and never returned, many others came back but remain financially paralyzed, and others are just intractable. I've passed by these former homes every day in my neighborhood for years, and I'm tired of seeing pieces of my community become dangerous ruins and expressing nothing but despair. It's time to flip the script.
But what can be done with a house where there is nothing left but the frames of its exterior walls? The answer is rather obvious to me - turn the open floor plan into a giant ball pit! A ball pit, 30 feet long, 16 feet wide, 4 feet deep full of balls to jump and play in - and rather than waste everyone's time with those weak, boring 3" balls you'd find at McDonald's, I'm going for it all: using thousands of 10" and 15" soft, bouncy playground balls. Yes, these!
How will it work? With the property owner's permission and for NO admission fee, the ball pit will be open to the public (or at least those members of the public willing to assume risk for the fun they'll have); supervised kids, adults - anyone, everyone - will be welcome to take advantage of this new community resource for outdoor play, neighborly engagement, and communal socializing. Open during the day and in the evening, there will be special events including live music, projected film screenings, and more, but most often the ball pit will be just an arena for glorious, glorious play. Netting will keep the balls in the pit, and foam padding on every exposed beam will make it safe and comfortable for everyone.
When and where? The ball pit will be ready to go by early May, with an official grand opening tentatively scheduled for Saturday, May 12, and will be open for about a month or six weeks - until it gets too hot, basically. The house is located at 2816 Burgundy St in the Marigny (that's New Orleans, LA, 70117). 
Who are you and what do you think you're doing? I'm Josh. When I do things out loud, I mostly do them with film, the past several years in New Orleans with Court 13 - from directing Big Freedia's music video for "Y'all Get Back Now" to working in the art department for the 2012 Sundance Film Festival Grand Jury Prize-winning Beasts of the Southern Wild. I've never built a giant ball pit in an abandoned house before, and that's fine by me.
Call this an interactive art installation, a neighborhood development initiative, or just totally crazy - to me it's simply a giant ball pit. Silly, I know, but it is serious too! There's really important work to do to bring attention to these dangerous properties and the slow progress of improving them in New Orleans. Fortunately the only way I know how to fight these serious problems is to facilitate absurd, riotous joy with equal and opposite force.
This is a two step process: the first has been to secure and clean up a seriously exposed and threatening location (for example, we have repaired an entire exterior wall that has nothing to do with the ball pit itself, except for the fact that it is part of the house, and was in imminent danger of collapsing onto adjacent, lived-in homes; pictures of all progress are available here). The second step is to turn the newly safe and functional building into something worthwhile. And bringing neighbors together, just to have a little fun in the spring sunshine, particularly in a place that used to be a problem beyond simply going to waste; that's something that's worthwhile to me.
How you can help: This project is really as simple as it sounds - all I'm going to do is thoroughly clean and secure the house, put up the netting/padding, fill it up with balls, and create a comfortable space to visit and spend time. This all takes a fair bit of money, and all donations will go directly into these four tasks, and it really is a more-is-more situation: more funding means a more secure house, a more comfortable area to rest and chat in, and so on. Extra funds will be thrown into publicity and maintenance once it's built. If you're in New Orleans and would like to participate in ANY part of the process, you are more than welcome - a ball pit is nothing without all of the people in it, starting with making it actually exist.
This will be a truly memorable and exciting addition to the community, and serve as a reminder that our neighborhoods are what we make them. In New Orleans, we can continue to ignore decay and abandonment but I think it's time we transform the neighborhoods ourselves, using the best and most abundant tool we have here: communal joy. It's happening, and I hope you'll join me.
Embrace the craziness-- get involved, and find us on facebook here! And thank you so, so much--
WE HAVE HIT OUR GOAL. The outpouring of support has been overwhelming, empowering, and inspiring. Your clicks, likes, and especially your donations have brought us attention from Grist, Next American City, a whole lot from The Gambit, the local news, and more. That's just the beginning, and only in the last few days. So what will we do now? Well, the basics have been covered: making the house safe and secure, and purchasing the raw materials for the pit. Any other funds we receive will go into making the experience a comfortable and enjoyable one on top of the glory of being in a giant ball pit. First on our wish list is providing a bathroom on-site (wouldn't that be nice?), establishing/maintaing an effective and efficient rain contingency, offering comfortable seating, having refreshments available, the list goes on. So let's keep going - we'll be open in 2 weeks!!! WHOA! SEE YOU THERE!

updates.update_content:
Through the extreme generosity of many, we have hit our goal in just half the time we gave ourselves. I can't even describe my excitement, except to equate it with some sort of combination of the largest fireworks show in history and only with the magic kind Gandalf busts out in Lord of the Rings, the first moon landing, the actuality of everlasting world peace, the defeat of Y2K, and reanimating the dinosaurs for modern times in Ben Ewen-Campen's lab having solved all the problems of Jurassic Park.
THIS IS GOING TO BE INCREDIBLE. The project has gotten a lot of attention, thanks entirely to your enthusiasm sharing it - see the main project page for links to various articles, it's wild! And for regularly updated pictures of the progress that's already happening every day, check out our .
